text: Originally rated on 2/14/09. I am trying this one in mid febuary so its not too fresh, brewed 6 of 2008. Anyway it pours a mid to deep amber body, no carbonation or head to speak of. Faint aroma of caramel malt, flavor had the same carmael malts but they were more pronuonced along with some spice, and it had a dry finish. Overall it was old but still decent anyway, i would like to give it another shot next fall

Botella of @Erzennel, Very Thanks for trade. 06/05/17. BBD:06/17
Color amarillo dorado con buena espuma blanca, aromas a medios a cereales con notas florarles, el sabor es a cereal con buenas notas a malta, cuerpo medio.
Röstmalziger Antrunk, vollmundiger erdiger Körper, der von leichten Fruchtnoten profitiert, im Abgang eine feine Honigsüsse gepaart mit harmonischen Hopfennoten.

Pours a rusty copper color. Thin off white head. Substantial lacing. Aroma of bread, nuts, and rye. 
Taste of toast, malt, caramel and nuts.
Great mouth feel. 
Was overjoyed to find a left over October fest beer in the middle of March. 
One of the best October fest beers Ive ever had.
12 oz bottle. Pours a nice burnished brown amber color with a small head. Initial hints of malty sweetness, biscuits and caramel. Minimal bitterness. Soft on the palate.
Bottle from trinkgut. Copper like colour. Decent small head. Nice malts. Tastes nice full with a small bitterness. Good.

Pours a lovely copper with a fine, staying, creamy, white head. Aroma has rye bread, sweet malts, soft grass. Medium carbonation, fine dryish and creamy mouthfeel. Flavour is quite sweet, caramel, still some rye bread, chewy malts. Lingering mild bitter grassy finish.

Bottle (as "Original Oktoberfest"). Pours bright copper color with off-white head and some lacing. Bread crust malt aroma with almond and caramel notes. Biscuit malt with caramel notes followed by dry hop bitterness (some grapefruit notes). Medium body. Dry, mouthcoating finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
I had tried both Paulaner and Ayinger Octoberfest Marzens prior to Hacker-Pschorr. I thought the other two were very good but this was noticeably better in aroma and taste.
Poured from a 12 OZ bottle into a pint glass. The appearance is a clear light brown color with a medium sized white head. The aroma is all malt. The taste is rich toasted malt. An excellent beer.

On Tap at Prost! Boise. Amber borwn with a modest soapy off-white head. Nice toasted malt and some honey like sweetness. A littel biter bite at the end. A good example of a style that is usually not my favorite.

From 500ml bottle. Copper coloured with a small white head. Tastes toasty caramel, a bit marzipan flavoured. Very good

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Bready aroma with caramel, toffee and honey. Slight wiff of alcohol. Moderate sweet with light bitterness. Nice and smooth and overall satisfying enough.

Bottle. It pours a clear copper color with a fizzy off white head. The aroma has toasted malt, hints of berries an caramel with light sulfury lager yeast. Mostly toasted malt. The flavor has some toasted malt and light caramel sweetness. Some corn-like adjunct. Light earthy and spicy bitterness. Pretty thin bodied. Just ok.

Nagy, tartós hab, barnába hajló bronzos szín. Malátás, enyhén fűszeres és édeskés illat. Picit édeskés, malátás alap, némi gyümölcsös aromával, enyhe olajossággal. Közepesen testes és szénsavasan, alig keserű. Szuperül sikerült, jól összerakott finom sör.
50cl bottle. Clear golden/amber - good head. Sweet malt aroma with grass - Sweet malt taste with some caramel to begin with subdued hop bitterness coming through - dryish finish, clean and pleasant.

50cl bottle. Clear golden-amber pour with an off-white head. Notes of mashed barley, crisp, bitter hops, bread, some red berries. Medium to light body, medium carbonation and a bitter, refreshing aftertaste.
Light malt aroma with hints of caramel. Decent head and coppery brown color. Clear. Well balanced malty sweetness and hop bitterness. Light to medium mouthfeel and clean finish.

50cl bottle from zymology, portugal. Appearance is clear and orange to copper. Head is persistent and thin. Taste is medium bitter and light sweet. Light to medium body. Finish is dry. Aroma is malt, hops, nutty, pepper, caramel, honey.
Clear brown with little beige head. Aroma is malts, dried fruit, alcohol, cobweb and paper. Taste is ugly alcoholic bitterness, slight malty sweetness. Dust and tobacoo in the finish. I hate it.

On tap, El Cervecero. Dorada, un dedo de espuma duradera. aroma escaso. Sabor agradablemente malteado, con excelente punto de gas. Miel, caramelo, contrapunto lupulado, de tono floral y justo amargor. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Clear amber color, small white head. Malt and grassy-hop aroma. Dry, medium bitter taste. Caramel and a bit grassy aftertaste, low average carbonation, thin mouthfeel.

Color cobre, translúcido, con capa de espuma blanca de dos dedos de grosor (buena retención). Aroma a grano, maltoso, algo floral y fresco. Sabor a malta con toques lejanos de malta tostada, dulce, con algo de amargor final procedente del lúpulo para redondear el trago. No esperaba tanto de este estilo de cerveza.

Huge disclaimer: I really dont know how to judge "Aroma" in decimals, since my mind processes only binary code ("Mmmm....smells like delicious, delicious beer..." or "Hrm....hope it at least *tastes* like beer"...)

Neither can I accurately adjudge the appearance, frequently, since I am 

a) wholly, happily ignorant of what color various styles are "supposed" to be and 

b) I dont care at all if a style looks improper and because

c) I am frequently guzzling straight from the bottle like a freaking Visigoth so 

d) I dont always know what the actual color of the beer is.

That being said...

I cracked this Hacker-Pschorr "Original Oktoberfest" (aliased, apparently from the "Oktoberfest-Marzen). It turned out to be very far away from the decent but unremarkable mass-produced German beer it appeared to be. 

It is full-mouthed, malty, non-hoppy, slightly sweet, notes of ochre and hominy. 

This stuff is well-made and it wont make you sorry you drank it.

Getting to like this style. Copper coloured with the merest hint of white head. Body is light/medium and low carb. Soft, plummy fruit and grass on the nose. Tastes of caramel malt, cookie dough and dark fruit.
Sample from bottle at Hy-Vee Oktoberfest. Poured amber, white head. Aroma was malty, sweet caramel, bread dough. Taste was caramel malt, mild sweetness.
500ml bottle fomr Alko, Pietarsaari. Pours dark amber with a medium-sized off-white head. Caramelly, malts, yeast, some dark fruits. Easy to drink a tasty. Very well balanced, quality brew. nice!

Clear copper color with minimal white head. Aroma of caramel malts, combined with grassy notes. Taste has caramel,malts,bread and grass. Sweet and easy to drink. Soft carbonation. Nicely balanced oktoberfest beer
On tap hopaholic. Deep yellow colour small white head. Nose is grainy, malty, sweet. Taste is also sweet, grainy. Very nice malt forward beer.
On tap at World of Beer (Charlottesville, VA). Aromas of fresh grain, grassy. Slightly hazy gold with a mostly lasting white head. Dry, grassy, grainy. Light-medium bodied.
Clear coppery body, minimal white head. Malty aroma, hints of corn. Slightly bitter taste with more malt and sweet malty finish. Watery, soft carbonation.

0.5L bottle. Pours a clear amber colour with a frothy off-white head. Aroma: malty, caramel, subtle dark fruit. Taste: malt, caramel, grains, light sweetness, subtle dark fruits and hops note. Moderate carbonation, light-medium body, light sweet and low bitterness. After four lacklustre Oktoberfest/Marzen in a row this is by far one of the better ones Ive tried so far, a very drinkable beer.
From cervezasespeciales. In Bavaria glass. Watching Los Soprano 4x02. Deliciously malty, sweet with a good bite of hops to compensate and a superb drinkability. My new prefered marzen

It pours clear with a cooper color and an off white moderate head. It has caramel aromas with low fruit and some sweetness to it. There are sweet flavors, but not overly. There is a slight plum-like flavoring to it with the caramel and a hint of cherry. It has a moderate body with low bitterness and a clean finish. Overall, this is one of the better Marzens that I have had with a clear flavor with a malt forward flavor and well done hop compliments.
Bottle at Appellation. Clear copperish brown. Nose is very malty, grain, caramel, sugar. Taste is grain, hay, clean, caramel sweet finish. Not really my style, lots ofmalts, slightly sugary.

0.5 l bottle from Alko Hakaniemi, Helsinki. Appearance is dark amber almost brown, clear, and with a nice white head. This is old school Märzen, not Helles like pale. Taste is sweetish from the dark malts and alcohol but there is also enough bittering hops to make it balanced. A kind of German bitter. This is no usual session stuff but for serious drinking with some less healthy food.

Clear golden amber with active carbonation. 3/4 inch bubbly, creamy-white head, receding somewhat slowly leaving thick lacing that slides down the glass just behind the receding head. Fairly strong aroma of bread, herbal and floral. Good feel, decent carbonation on the tongue, not at all thin. Initial taste follows the aroma with a bit of bittering to start. A mild middle with lots of complexity in the flavor. Finish is moderately clean with just enough bittering to balance the malts.
Bottle from Appellation dalry. Pours clear brown. Nose of apples, toffee, malts. Taste is malt loaf, heavy flavour but tannable.
On tap Na 7. Schode. Aroma of caramel. amber color, clear liquid, creamy white head. Medium bitterness, light sweetness. Taste of caramel, nuts. medium body,creamy texture,average carbonation.
Copper with a great head caramel aroma and taste somewhere sweetness well rounded and easy drinking alcohol well hidden
Clear malty aroma. Some boogie in taste. Some sweet märzen characteristics. Caramel probably. Light. Id drink this in the fest.

Sweet maltiness that sits on top of an almost wheat-styled ale. The sweetness is not over powering as it's brought back down with a nice tingling fizz and very mild bitter. Pretty good.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a vibrant golden-amber colored beer with a huge, creamy white head.

Smells of fresh cut grass, dried garden herbs and a cookie dough malt backbone with a note of wild honey instead of chocolate, wrapped up by straw. 

Has a lively, well fitting mouthfeel, adding a refrehing feel to the light bodied, otherwise malty and straw defined beer. 

Tastes of sweet straw, with a fizziness from the bubbly carbonation, which adds a coppery hint, blending into the malts. Turns even sweeter during the mid palate with a late dry quality, bringing forest leafes to the palate, adding some depth to the so far one dimensional drinking experience.

An easy drinker, which turns out to be a tad too sweet to convince entirely. Its malty straw profile defines the taste from the beginning till the end, with not much else going on.
Tap at One Pint Pub, Helsinki. Colour us clear dark orange with small white head. Aromas and flavors: Grain, some sweetness, some harshness and malts.

Bottle from a Lazy Dog
Deep golden color bordering on amber with a frothy off white head that persists. Rich caramelized maltiness with bits of floral hops and crackery pilsner to round it out. Pretty tasty Oktoberfest.
500ml bottle. Pours dark amber with medium sized white head. Caramel malts, yeast, some dark fruits. Quite easy to drink. Very well balanced, quality brew. Just not that big fan of the style.

I dont know, maybe its just me. These authentic German Oktoberfests generally taste the same to me. This one also pours a fairly dull orange with average carbonation and head. The aroma is mild, slightly sweet, slightly syrupy, maybe a little more hop character than other Oktoberfests. The flavor is more of the same but even more muted than other beers in the style. Meh.
Not bad but the marzen are not really my favorites. Looks pretty good in a plastic glass.

Pours up a deep Amber, crystal clear, with a moderate white foam head and nice lacing. Aroma is rich caramel malts, a touch of toast, and a strong dark fruit, plum and cherry smell. Taste deep and rich caramel, malts, a light toasted bread, and a fruitiness thats a blend of cherry and raisin. Some tea like taste on the finish. Moderately sweet Mouth feel, but not too sweet. Medium bodied, definitely heavier than some other Marzens. Low to moderate carbonation. Top notch Marzen. Leaves a fruity and tea like flavor that is typical for a German made Marzen, and less emphasis on the toast and roast qualities. Very easy drinking and good.

330ml bottle. 10/16 best by date. Appearance: Deep Amber, perfectly clear, with a moderate white foam head and nice lacing. 
Aroma: Rich caramel maltiness, a touch of toast, and a strong dark fruit of plum and cherry. 
Taste: Deep, rich caramel and bready maltiness, a light toasted bread, and a moderate fruitiness thats a blend of cherry and raisin. Tastes like tea on the finish. Low bitterness is just enough to prevent this beer from being too sweet 
Mouthfeel: Medium bodied, definitely heavier than some fellow Marzens, with a low to moderate carbonation. 
Finish: Very bready with a touch of toast on the finish, and tea leaves. 
Overall: Top notch Marzen. Leaves a fruity and tea like flavor that is typical for a German made Marzen, and less emphasis on the toast and roast qualities. Very easy drinking and perfect for a cool fall afternoon

330ml bottle. This pours a very clear light amber color. The aroma is very clean. The taste is right on with flavors of a Helles merged with a Dunkles which is what a great Märzen/Oktoberfest should taste like. What a shame that I can drink this in the US, but it is not served in Munich at the Oktoberfest where they charge a fortune for regular Helles lager.
Klares kupferfarben mit reichlich Schaum. Malzig, etwas Karamell, süßlich, würzig, sehr süffig.

[2015-10-23] Kullankeltainen, kirkas, valkoinen vaahto. Tuoksu on ohramaltainen. Maku on pääosin runsaan ohramaltainen, taustalla myös hieman alkoholin poltetta. (Alkuperäinen arvio 2009-10-02, 30 pts.)

Bottle 50cl
@ The Beer Garden Store, Madrid, Spain.
A: Amber.
T: Cereal, sweet, caramel.

On tap at PIB 2016, pours a clear copper golden with a small white head. Aroma brings out cereal malt and bready notes, barely any hops. Flavour brings out toasted chestnuts upfront, with a fair amount of bready and cereal malt sweetness. Clean and well-made. This is how you do a marzen. Solid.

On tap in Florida. Crystal clear bright Amber, thin ring of white head. Sweet malty caramel aroma. A touch of soap. Medium body, very light fizz, oily. Caramel and biscuit. Faint hops. Smooth palate. Nice and very dark for style.
Old rating. Best before 04.05.05.  Nice malty brew with sweetish hints. The beer is round but not too deep. Malty but nice.

Flasche 0,5l: Dunkles Gold, glasklar, kräftiger feinporiger Schaum; in der Nase schöne Würze, leichte Süße, Getreide, leichte Fruchtigkeit, Malz; süß und süffig im Körper, angenehme Würze, malzig, leicht gehopft, leichte Säure; würziger Nachgang mit leichter Säure

Drunk from 50cl bottle bought from Bierhuis in Ossett. Superb smooth Oktoberfest brew.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

(Hacker-Pschorr Oktoberfest Märzen) Swing top bottle 500 ml at home, served into a dimpled mug. ABV 5.8%
Amber coloured body, clear, with a big and thick off-white head with average retention. 
On the aroma sweet malts, caramel and toffee, biscuit. 
Nice taste, light caramel, toffee, biscuit, german hops.
Medium body, good carbonation, pleasantly dry on the palate.
Good.

Clear amber color with off-white head. Aroma is mainly malty with some alcohol. Taste starts with bread crust and some caramel. Overall its really balanced between sweet and bitter. Body is medium and carbonation is quite low for the style. Really simple and boring.

Aroma leaves a tad to be desired, love the appearance. Great head, dissipates fast though. Taste is a medium bitter with a long finish. My fave Oktoberfestbier. Love this. 5.8ABV but hides it well. Nice caramelisation, perfect with a burger or schweinhaxe
A mellow and slightly sweet Märzen beer. Seems richer and sweeter as you proceed. Leaves a dry aftertaste. Good but by no means great.
Fad på die Wiesn i Munchen. Farven er gyldengul og skumkronen er hvid. Aromaen er malt, karamel og brød medens smagen er malt og tørret frugt. For sødlig til min smag.

How: Draught.
Where: The Bishops Arms Gamla Stan, Stockholm.
Appearance: Amber colour with an off-white head.
Aroma: Malt, caramel, bread.
Body: Medium body and carbonation.
Flavour: Malt, caramel, some dried fruit.
Medium body. Amber colour. Toasty taste with malt, caramel and a bit of nutty flavour. Balanced taste

I never get these as fresh as Id like but this seems to be doing pretty OK. Its clear amber in color w/ a thick, creamy white head and lots of lace. It has a mildly nutty malt character and succeeds in being fairly malty w/o being all kinds of sweet. This is balanced by a nice dose of earthy/herbal hops. This is medium bodied w/ somewhat brisk carbonation, nice and flavorful and very drinkable.
Aromas, dulces, malta, herbales con punto ahumado/tostado, en boca mismas sensaciones, con más dulzor, y final más seco. Me gusta bastante, fácil de beber. Bien compensada
November 26, 2015 - bottle from Chuck. Light brown pour with some head. Aroma of sweet malt, caramel and grain.
50 cl. bottle. Clear dark amber colour with a white head. Aroma and flavour of malt, fruit, hops, caramel and bitterness.
Bottle. Pours amber in color with small cream colored head. Aroma is caramel malt with biscuit notes. Sweet caramel malt flavor. Light bodied. Standard for the style.
Appearance is small white head with clear amber. Aroma is sweet malts. Taste is a nice balance between sweet malts and bitterness. Overall one of the better Oktoberfests.
Flaske 500ml fra Alko Muonio. Drukket i Skibotn 4 Okt 15. Mørk gyldenbrun. Lavt skum som forsvinner raskt. Beskjeden maltaroma. Litt mais. Smaken det samme. Hint av krydder. Litt tørr avslutning.
Clear amber pour with minimal white skim. Aroma is bready malt, as is the flavor with a light sweentess. Very smooth, and quite a nice example of the style. Not my favorite, but its up there.

Review baes on the BJCP2015 guidelines (style 6A). Bottle 50 cl - Batch L22551Y. AROMA: predominant malt aroma with a bready, toasty crust character. no hop aroma. clean lager profile. APPEARANCE: orange-ambar color and translucent. off-white medium head with styçe average retention. TASTE: predominant malty flavour with a slight toasty bread crust character. low bitterness with a malty and almost sweet finish. clean lager profile. PALATE: medium body with a light smooth texture. medium-low carbonation. OVERALL: a Marzen style beer, tipped towards malty sweetness.

Look; off white head, bright clear amber body. Aroma; clean malts, caramel, leaves, grass, hops, milky butter on bread. Taste; solid malts, caramel, bread, leaves, butter on bread - leading to a malty finish with leaves. On palate nice. Overall; very clean, forward leaning taste, a good brew. Bottled. Clear, a dark amber colour, and a small, light cream coloured head that soon disappeared. A pilsner-like nose with a touch of caramel sweetness. Flavours are dry, nutty, and savoury, with a clean, crisp pilsner palate.

500ml Swing top bottle poured into a Strassburg glass. Use by March 2016. 
This beer reminded me that how a beer tastes can be greatly influenced by what you are eating. This beer was sweet caramel malty goodness when drunk whilst eating a lightly salty rosti. When drunk on its own, not nearly as sweet and had a bittersweet aftertaste. Went back to eating rosti in between mouthfuls of marzen and fantastic tasting beer again. So enjoy, but enjoy more with pretzels or crisps etc...

330 ml bottle bought at The Q-Club in SoHo, Central.
Clear amber copper colour; One-quarter finger head and residual soapy white foam which fades in 10 seconds; Good sticky lacing with very slight carbonation; Sweet aroma of amber malt, with light burnt tire, strong honey, caramel, molasses, light bread, light lemon and thin grass; Mid to light sweet taste of thin amber malt, with notable roastyness, strong grains, molasses, light caramel, light biscuits, thin lemon, moderate bitter hops and grass; Light body. Close to watery palate; Mouth feel is fair amber malt in a paper-thin back ground. No richness whatsoever. Fair roastyness and light caramel. Annoying graininess. Moderate sweetness. Lemon and extract bitterness to round. Hmmm Hoppiness is light lemon and thin grass in nose, and relatively stronger in taste. Bitterness is from extract, strong but artificial for a lasting, high astringent bitter and sweet finish; Slightly dry after taste. Roasty and strong bitter to mouth.

Comments: I was expecting this one to be good, but the burnt tire smell got off badly, plus the watery body, grainy taste and extract hoppiness makes this a strong but unconvincing Maerzen. Nah!

Open the bottle and get greeted by a pleasant and prominent scent of hops and caramel. Pours an equally pleasant clear bronze with a nice tan head that lasts nicely. The flavor is equally pleasant and whats expected from a good Bavarian beer with touches of bread and hops with a nice bittersweet tail. Ends clean and well rounded. Definitely one I would like to have again.

Bottle from speciaalbeer Leiden.
decent white head. Clear golden pour. Some caramel. Light bitterness.
Tap at Erzbierschof Zurich. A mostly malt dominated beer, almost a syrup. Some caramel. Feels a bit watery though.

500ml swing-top bottle, many thanks to Finn. Crystal clear amber coloured body under a firm pearl white head reduced to a remaining patchy surface. Dotted spots on the glass. Moderate aroma of bread and dough, mid-sweet. The flavour profile is a made up of caramel, bread and noble hops followed by mild bittersweet tail. Clean and rounded on the swallow. Medium bodied. Drinks very well (at home, Tromsø 16.10.2015).
Malty, bready and quite dry with a little spice. Rounded bitter-sweet hops with subtle grass and pine coming through. Loved the tent!

On tap. Served a coppery color with a nice head that fades slowly. Aroma of malt sweetness, bit of hops and hint of herbs. Taste of mild malt sweetness with a bit of grain. Nice bitterness and a clean finish. Moderate body, with a smooth festive feel. Enjoyable beer than goes down easy. Good way to kick-off the season.
Average off-white frothy head with good retention. Clear yellow light amber colour. Aroma is clean, malty and toasted sweet. Taste is malty, sweet start and dryest finish.
Copper colour, big head wiht decen retention, good lace. Sharp smell of herbs, with some caramel and banana. Medium body, good carbonation. Taste of fruits (banana), caramel, herbs. Really good.
Fliptop bottle. Copper in color, off-white head. Nice malty bready notes in aroma. Similar in taste with quite nice malty notes being present. Bit on the sweeter side, otherwise good.

pours a clear amber with a medium beige head. Light malt and grass aroma. Full malt flavor with some modest hop bitter to counter. Pleasant bittersweet finish. Very well balanced. Probably the best Oktoberfest Ive had yet. Good beer!

On tap at Oktoberfest. More bitter mouthful than other. Not bad through. Bit malty 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from the Rugby Tap. Looks very nice in the glass, much darker than other traditional Oktoberfests. Grassy, caramel, toasted aromas. Taste is biscuity, caramel, grassy, bit of toffee in there. Slightly sweet finish. Decent.

A quite dark, yellow with light brown notes. A blond head is quite big but decreasing. Aroma has strong maltyness, some grass, not so fresh as should be. Taste has sweet maltyness, some bitterness but thats not drying the mouth enough, some grass. Medium bodied, smooth, nice carbonation. Easy to drink as this is brewed. Nothing special but the glass is quickly empty.

From 0,5l patent bottle, BBD: 06/2016 Pours clear amber liquid, medium frothy tan head, fell down quickly, Aroma: malty, caramel, bit grainy, Taste: medium sweet, light to medium bitter, light sour, malty, caramel, bit grainy, light hopy, bready, Palate: medium body, slick to creamy texture, average carbonation, medium long caramel finish, Overall: drinkable, but nothing exciting.

Bready, caramel malty aroma with a surpringly boozy nose (although its currently room temp). Subtle banana hints. Lovely, actually quite unusual colour of clear rust. Flavour is sweet,, smooth caramel with an overarching bready flavour and a slight sharpness from the alcohol. Whilst the beer is sweet, the breadiness gives a very savoury impression. A really nice example of the style, only criticism is the lack of masking of the alcohol flavours.
小麦の嫌な感
Weak Sweet malt aroma and a clear dark gold body. Flavour is a slightly vegetable sweet malt mix. Not especially amazing.

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2015 0,5l Bügelflasche. Enttäuschendes Aroma, kaum Duft. Vielleicht Getreide und Karamell. Sehr schöne klare Bernsteinfarbe. Fester Schaum. Malzig Hopfiger Geschmack mit Waldhonignoten. Vollmundig und doch süffig. Brotgeschmack im Abgang.

Bottle from Alko, Helsinki. Pours dark bronze with a little white head, a bit dark for a märzen. The aroma features hayish, bready maltiness with some herbs and a touch of grass - malty, but also subtly hoppy. Taste is light sweet, fairly rich in pale malty flavours. Dries toward finish but only lightly, low in hoppiness. The palate is medium-bodied, slick and smooth. Malty, fairly full-bodied märzen.

(500ml swing top ) In a pint jug . I have drank this several tims , but neglected to rate it . This is an easy to chug,drink, swill Marzen - that has that grimy slightly gritty texture you get in dark lagers, kinda industrial . Good fest beer either way ! Nose of brown sugar , pie crust , apple ester , syrupy caramel , hay . It looks like a Germanic dark lager ! It dranks pretty well, serviceable ... A pass out after giant pint steins kinda sensibility !
Bottle from Cornelius. Crystal clear bright Amber, thin ring of white head. Sweet malty caramel nose. A touch of soap. Medium body, very light fizz, oily. Caramel and biscuit. Faint hops. Good.
Bottle, Ann Arbor, MI, USA via Plum Market. Pale amber, sweet, caramel, some faint hops.

Pours clear light to medium brown with medium frothy head. Aroma is malty, caramel, nuts, bread, honey, broth. Very light hops. Medium malty, light bitter, straw, cereal. Short finish, body is medium, palate is oily, carbonation is average.

Draught @ BAJT. Pours clear Amber with a frothy and creamy offwhite head that leaves some sparse trace on the glass while dissipating. Smell is tiny malty, slightly fruity estery and slightly floral with dark bread, caramel, red pears, hay, minerals and lemon peal. Taste is slightly sweet, tiny bitter, very tiny sour, slightly malty, fruity estery and tiny floral. Mouthfeel is soft, tiny round, tiny dry, very tiny tart and light to medium bodied. Finish is tiny sweet and slightly bitter with dark bread, caramel, toffee, red pears, grapes, hay, minerals and lemon peal. Bit dry for a Märzen and to heavy on the fruity esters to suit me.

Draught at Bishops Arms, Gamla Stan. Clear copper/amber beer with a decent offwhite head. Malty caramel aroma, bready, caramel, dark bread, some grainy notes. Malty caramel flavor, dark bread, raisins, citrus, some hay. Decent beer.

Clear amber pour big head medium carbonation aromas citrus grain lemon melon hay the flavours grain malt sweet barley hay very rich malty tastes grassy smooth and sweet as it should be going down could be a little stronger in taste the finish best notes sweetness mild bitter good hop body good beer

Dark red in my seidel, not big on the nose. Light, nutty and semi-sweet going down the hatch. Transitions to umami with a trace of bitterness, then quickly fades away. Harder to find than it used to be, its still one heck of a treat.

Colore ambrato, schiuma non eccessiva.
Odore tenue, maltato, cereali, leggero caramello.
Sapore maltato, caramellato, predonmina il sapore dolce, con lamaro poco presente.
W aromacie karmelowość oraz słodowość. W smaku głównie słodowość. Dobrze zbilansowane, pijalne. Przeciętne wysycenie.

Ive tried all the mainstream German Oktoberfestbiers I can get and one thing Ive noticed is that none of them have any real hop presence. Hacker-Pschorr Oktoberfest seems to be the exception as there is a noticeable, but reserved, amount of spicy hops and a fairly clean palate with subtle sweetness. Not a delicious beer by any means, but probably the best of the mediocre bunch.

I poured an 11.2oz bottle into my OktoBEERfest mug.

Appearance: Very dark amber color, almost straight up brown. Clear with some calm carbonation visible. Forms a rather small, off-white, soapy head which dissipates rather quickly and leaves no lacing on the glass.

Smell: A noticeable skunky aroma at first (likely due to the dark olive-green bottle color), its easily tolerable and ignored. Otherwise its a mild aroma thats generic lager at the core.

Taste: Upon my first swig of Hacker-Pschorr Oktoberfest I noticed something I hadnt in any other German brews of the style: hops. Or to be more precise: bitterness. Its not this is a high IBU beer full of citrus or pine flavor, just that theres more kick to this palate than most. The palate is mostly clean - like a dark lager with all the off-flavors and undesirable qualities removed. You can tell its a lager but it doesnt scream "lager" on the tongue. A consistent bitterness throughout with mild toffee sweetness on the second half. Just as it finishes the bitterness reemerges for a swift kick of spice before fading away cleanly. Its only a degree or two better than most beers of this sort, but enough to warrant a genuine thumbs up from me (dont expect me to jump for joy about it, though).

Drinkability: Hacker-Pschorr Oktoberfest seems to be a bit more crisp than most, but the mouthfeel is still comfortable and the finish is just as smooth as the rest - if not more so. Its a little bit refreshing, too. The 5.8% ABV weight is about the same as most, but at least this one has a little more body to it.

Es schmeckt malzig, hopfig und würzig. Natürlich ist es schön süffig, der Nachgeschmack gibt mit seinem Hopfenaromen noch einmal einiges her. Fazit: Mir schmeckt es!
	
Test vom 24.9.2008, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 10,10,12,11,13,12 - 11,40
Crisp, clean, refreshing...not much else. Light grainy and cereal malts with a hint of grass and metallic hops. Sweet and lightly honeyed middle with mild dryness on the finish. Overall, quite bland.

Bottle, bought @ Reading Beer Festival. Opens with a gentle fission. Pours clear dark amber. Gentle aroma from the hops. Flavour is deep caramel, light almost cherry fruits. Marzipan? Low bitterness, followed by lingering faint sweetness with slight bitterness. Lovely beer.
Giant can and giant cup, tastes awesome, very well balanced and true to the style.

Oktoberfest beer in May? Yes Please! Pretty darn good Marzen - Lovely amber with pillowy head. Faint toffee  nose. Full, slightly chewy - malt driven. Toffee, bread and soft bitter finish. Well rounded.
500 mL bottle into a pint glass at Reading Beer Festival 2012.  Copper, clear and flat.  Nice aroma.  Fresh, a touch oakey, very drinkable, bitter, hint of malt.

Nov 2009: Brown flip-top bottle containing 0.5 litres of Marzen. Poured into a pint sized vase shaped glass (Old Speckled Hen branded).

Lovely copper body with an off-white head on top.

Caramel and toffee esters in the aroma, but it isnt a sweet smelling beer by any means. Malted biscuits come in to play as the beer warmed a little.

Toffee again in the taste, a lot going on though, some cereal flavours are also present, then hazel nuts came to mind as I sipped my way down the glass. So hazel nuts dipped in a semi-sweet toffee mix liquified and then fermented with some yeast, hops and malts is what Ive come up with to describe this beer!

A warmth, depth, and richness just exude from this beer, very, very drinkable indeed.

Originally reviewed: 10/25/10. This one was at the top of my list of Festbiers to try this fall. 12oz bottle poured into a mug. Pours a transparent dark ferric rusty color. A small off-white head rests atop. No lace. Scents of bread, caramel, and light minerals. 

The mouth is moderately full. Good carbonation. Refreshingly wet. Excellent bounty of sweet malts and fresh bread. This beer nails the Festbier flavor dead on. Hints of caramel, toffee, and just a wisp of bitterness. I could drink this all day, or month for that matter. Thisll be the one I stock my fridge with every autumn from here on out. Great beer.
Beautiful copper tone.  Smooth and roasted chest nutty with low carbonation and a nice finish.  Small head.  Sweet  at first and lasting grainy finish.  Extra point for the swing top lid.
500ml Swing top bottle. Deep amber colour with huge head. Aroma is sweet malty, grassy. Flavour is malty, grassy hops.
TAP @ Thirsty Pagan: Not a lot too it. Amber pour with a tan head. Aroma and taste are sweet malts. Watery and thin mouthfeel. Meh.
Cloudy amber color, smoky and malty, medium bodied. Bubbly, delicious. Really wanna go to oktoberfest to try the authentic if its said to be better than this.
11.2 oz bottle.  Pours deep smoky amber in colour, greyish amber head.  Nice malty aroma and taste, slightly smoky.  Pretty good.

Tasting from September 2011.Into a dimple, chilled from the bottle. Not too lively a pour as I had anticipated. A deep tawny copper, bright and radiant in the lights with a lot of fine carbonation that is slow to rise. A beige hued, rocky and tight crown settles and is mostly lasting. Very dusty aroma; lots of malt, gritty, toasted and raw with inklings of fresh cracked pepper, dried, mown grass, earth and lime zest. The Noble Hallertauer is quite pronounced, unexpected in a Märzen. First sip sees more hops than malt, the finish being assertively bitter and dry. Spicy, woody, herbal and earthy in back and in the swallow. Malt builds, gives a meaty back bone to it. Toasted, rich malts, lightly tannic rusty in back to add depth. Firm body with a soft, clean and sprightly mouthfeel. The balance and harmony is wonderful. Overall it is quite dry but has good body and drinks well even as it warms. A lipsmacking good Märzen! (50cL, BBE 01/12, Cellarbrations Carlisle)

A nice sweet bitter pilsener for drinking together with eating sausages. Foam sticks to upper lip and prelongs the pleasure. Good clear color.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From a 500ml bottle on 25/3/2012. Pours a clear medium amber with a smallish head. Has a pleasant light malty aroma. Flavour wise, this is very malty, with caramel and a touch of toffee. A good, solid marzen.
bottle, good til 05/12, poured quite nice amber hue, white strong head, I loved it, aroam malty sweet candy corn,taste, same candy corn sweetness, expands to malty smooth backend, overall awesome!
user_location: @RED BHUT JOIKIAS!, Paulsboro, New Jersey, USA

text: Probably the best you can find in Oktoberfest, so theres nothing more to say...
Bottle. Pours a nice dark amber with a creamy tan head. Malty german nose gives off some caramel. Taste is nicely rounded with peppery lager carbonation. Easy to drink.
An original is always worth drinking in order to know the history of the beer world.  Toasted barely notes mixed with thick caramelized sugars.
This is the original, this is the one with the right hops, the right combination that isnt too heavy but clearly bigger and bolder than your plain Munich lager.
Bottle pours a clear copper with a thin white head. Scent is malt and toffee. Taste is sweet with a mild bitterr finish.

oktoberfest session during sunday football, into my mug pours an amber hue, big foamy ofrf white head, tons of retention. Malt, noble hop, and alchohol in the nose. Taste is similar, bends to the sweet side. YUM. drinkable and enjoyable, best Marzen I had today.
12oz bottle in TN, pre-birthday. It was okay but honestly not a great fest beer. I just would have liked the sweeter malt and hop balance to be more pronounced. Fine.

Bottle. Clear, dark golden. Small white head. Hoppy aroma. Slightly sweet. Not bad. A little sticky. Sweet, malty aftertaste.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Pours a nice dark amber with a creamy tan head. Malty german nose gives off some caramel. Taste is nicely rounded with peppery lager carbonation. Easy to drink.

Review from notes at World of Beer - Fort Myers on 11/17/11.

Poured on draft into a shaker pint glass. 

Appearance: Pours a dark caramel with gold highlights and a 1/2 finger off-white head. Minimal lacing.

Smell: Sweet German malt with a touch of earthy notes.

Taste: Sweet German malt up front followed by lightly bitter earthy hops in the middle ending with sweet malt at the finish. 

Mouthfeel: Light-to-medium-bodied with a good amount of carbonation.

Drinkability: Decent drinkability. You wouldnt want more than a couple.

Overall: Slightly above average beer overall. There are far better Oktoberfest beers available.
Bottle. Dark amber with a thin white head. Sweet malt dominates the aroma and flavour with minimal bitterness. Low carbonation. The lager equivalent of mild ale. Dull.

Sorry for the german rating, but this is a lousy rating from my "newbie" time (2007-2009), and its not worth of being translated. I just added it for the statistics, and to complete my backlog!

Im Glas schauts herrlich bernsteinfarbend aus, geziert von einer wahren Prachtkrone, die sich mittelporig und standhaft zeigt. Geruchlich dominiert vorerst mal der Malz. Der Antrunk ist ebenfalls intensiv malzig und sehr würzig. Mit jedem Schluck wirds süßer und einige karamellige Töne mischen sich bei. Dieses süffige, würzige Oktoberfestbier trinkt sich wirklich super!!!
Deep caramel hue. Solid, malty, full body Oktoberfest Marzen. Delicious. Slow, low malt aftertaste. Very good.

Mid amber with strong malted milk aroma. Very little bitterness. Heavy and sweet.
bread, spruce, basement aromas, bubblegum, golden, cloudy, white foam, rocky head, medium sweetness, very bitter, medium sourness, sticky, full body, bitter,

Hacker-Pschorr Original Oktoberfest is a crystal clear amber lager with a thin white head that quickly fades to a film.  It has a sweet, malty aroma, like bread and caramel.  Its pretty light bodied, smooth and a little flat.  The finish is a little watery and metallic.  It has a faint taste of slightly sweet malt and a little melanoid.  Theres a touch of leafy bitterness at the finish.  The aftertaste is grainy and bready.  Its a beer.  I dont know if Id drink more than one of these, but I finished my pint with no problem.

Amongst the best Oktoberfests that Ive tried. Flowery aroma with caramel (maybe cereal) malt sweetness that translate to taste. Super smooth and clean with a sneaky 6% abv. Turn up the polka and kick a few of these back Prosit!

UPDATED: NOV 8, 2014 Poured from a bottle into brandy snifter.  Nice copper color with a decent head...but it didn?t stay.  Crisp taste and easy to drink; though a little boring.   Orig 1.3.12.  Update 11.8.14.  Not much different.   Taste is caramel and malty.   3.1 to 3.2.

Bottle (500ml):
Dark malts on the nose along with some light smelling hops that are blended throughout. There is a sweet brown sugar type aroma along with some earthy hops towards the middle and the end. I can also sense some biscuit like notes towards the end.

Brownish amber with a clear body and a thin, bubbly white head that slowly recedes to a thin and patchy, soapy lacing around the top of the beer.

The taste is mainly made up from caramel and the earthy hops from the nose along with hoppy, biscuit malts. There is a warm and mildly bitter finish to the beer.

This one had a warm, medium body with a thick and mildly bitter finish, overall carbonation is mild here.

Not amazing but a solid effort from this one, its not the best Hacker-Pschorr beer that I have tried but the brewery usually produces enjoyable beers. It went down easily enough and had some good malty flavours throughout but its probably not one I would recommend.

1001 Beers To Try:
Bottle. Clear dark amber body with big off-white head. Aroma-taste; malt forward sweetish light caramel, toast with a long sweetish toasty malt finish. Medium bodied; mdoerate carbonation.

A rich vienna red in colour, The foam is initialy dense but fades to nothing quickly. Its light to medium carbonation is only just acceptable. The nose provides pleasant floral hop notes and the flavour is quite malty slightly sweet and a hint of yeasty breadiness presents itself.

Tap. Lovely copper color with a prominent white head. The nose is sweet, light caramel. The taste is nicely balanced medium sweetness. The bodys medium, a bit heavier than other marzens Ive tried. The carbonation is lively.

Aroma: Difficult to discern, but a clean aroma.

Appearance: Amber body. Small dissipating head. No lacing. 

Taste: Wheaty taste with hints of lemon. Pure, clean and very easy to drink. 

Palate: A relatively high ABV for a lager, but not overpowered by the alcohol. 

Overall: Delicious, pure taste.

UPDATED: OCT 24, 2016 Bottle. Amber, average and mostly diminishing head. Moderate, malty and sweetish aroma, some bread and caramel, light fruitiness/notes of honey and light hoppyness. Body is medium, malty and sweetish flavor, some bread and caramel, light hoppyness. Finish is average, malty and lightly sweetish - sweetish, light - some caramel and light bread, light hoppyness with fain alcohol. Caramel sweetish märzen/lacks character - way too sweet for me. Dont believe the hype.

Ive had this beer in Germany, and Ive had it here a few times. This most recent batch (obtained in 2011) was not up to par with others I have had.
Very small head that didnt last long. No nose to speak of, except for some licorice-like notes.
Poor body. Very bubbly, almost irritating on the tongue. Flavor was all of burnt malt, no hops at all. My guess is that this must be from a batch that didnt travel well, because Hacker-Pschorr beers are generally very, very good.
Clear amber body with short lasting head. Soft caramel on the nose with the same in the taste along with some biscuit notes and soft bitterness.

Ar: Grassy with slight cracker notes.
Ap: Crystal-clear deep orange-amber with a large light tan head - good retention, nice thick lacing.
T: Clean grassy hops and light cracker maltiness up front - toasted notes continue with a slight sulfur flavor - finish is very lightly bitter with lingering light toasted malts.
P: Medium-light body with medium-high carbonation - dry finish.
O: Solid octoberfest - clean, toasty and dry.

Bottle from Stirchley WInes, Birmingham. Nice colour, but no head. The mouthfeel is surprisingly smooth, but the taste is a little lacking. Some sugary, treacly malt, but not much finish and no aftertaste. Clean.

Bottle @ home. Clear, caramel brown appearance with an ivory head. Today, caramel, Munich malty, hay, noble hoppy aroma. Medium bodied, good carbonation. Caramel, Munich malty, slightly nutty, grassy hoppy flavor. Smooth, easy drinking but I prefer Paulaners offering better.

Bottle at home with Sev. Pours a copper colour with a thin beige head. Aroma of chocolate, toffee and roasty malt. Roasty malt flavour also with caramel, honeycomb and toffee and a blood iron tang. Moderate carbonation and CO2 prickle. Foamy mouth-feel with a warming alcohol hum.

500ml swing-top bottle (exp 3/12). Nice clear copper-brown pour with a decent off white head. Nose and taste is caramel malts with a hint of nuts but it is not as sweet as you would imagine by that description (a plus point in my opinion). Light dry hop finish. Light-medium body for the ABV with a smooth easy drinkability. Probably the one I would go for at a German Oktoberfest.

Pour is darker brown with some slight orange around the edges and a thing white head. Aroma is slight caramel with some yeast and spices in the background. Flavor is spices, pumpkin, caramel, with some toasted grain in the finish. A tad bland, but a good marzen overall.

The pour is a slightly lighter amber with a decent enough head that simmers down after a moment. Lots of sweet malts on the nose.  The body falls into the medium range. The taste has a smooth bitterness with the emphasis on the malt character.  This is why it is so good.

500ml bottle poured a light brown color with a small off-white head and some very thin lacing.  Aroma is caramel malts and some flowery hops.  Taste is dominated by a malty sweetness and finishes with a light hop bitterness.  Medium body and some nice carbonation lend a nice mouthfeel.  This is a solid brew and a recommended tasting experience.

Best by 05/12.

Pours a clear, dark golden orange color with a one finger frothy white head that immediately settles into a thin ring.  Not much in the way of lacing.  

Sweet malty aroma with subtle autumnal spice notes.  Lots of sweet caramel and toffee along with some nutmeg and cinnamon.  Maybe some brown sugar.  

Medium bodied and fuller than expected for the style(read German example) with a nice balance of zesty spice and sweet malt.  Still its very easy to put down.  Lots of sweet caramel, toffee and biscuit with hints of pepper, clove, nutmeg and brown sugar.  Complex and much better than I anticipated.  Sessionable as well.
Pours a  pale brown with a head which disappears quickly. Hints of toffee, caramel and malt on the nose.  Taste is caramel, malt and biscuit..
Has a roasted caramel taste. Deep clear brown color. Mild sweetness. Almost no head. Finishes dry with little after taste.

12 oz bottle. $7.99 a six pack at a local Market Basket grocery store. Pours a clear brown, cola like, color with a 1/2" white head. Sweet caramel, butterscotch aroma. Taste is likewise. Light to moderate in body with low carbonation. Easy to drink. One dimensional, but quire tasty.
Keg in Craft Beer Co. Colour is brown, white foam head, excellent lacing. Nose is quite fruity hops, dry grassy, roasted notes. Taste is quite fruity hops, roasted flavours.

(bottle)  Bottle opened with a delightful pop.  Rich caramel and yeast aroma.
Mid amber colour.  Fine white head which laced the glass.
Flavours of sweet toffee and almond.  Hops are present but not overpowering.  Finish is not heavy, despite the initial caramel hit.  This is definitely in my top 3 Märzens.  Prost!

bottled. pours crystal clear light brown/amber, with a medium tan tight head. aromas of roasted malt, earth and basement. a touch of sweetness and sourness. light bodied thin mouth feel and a bit flat. a finish of sweet roasted malt on the tongue, which finishes quickly and sweetly,

Nice spicy and rich aroma for an Oktoberfest. It pours with a thin head, a deep amber color (just a shade darker than other Oktoberfests Ive seen), and has substantial legs. Smooth rich & spicy taste to match the aroma with some decent caramel flavor. Really like this one. It tastes like Fall as a season should taste.

Just had my first taste of this the other night. Again this begs the question, why o why cant American breweries produce a beer as good as this? With the exception of some of the USA micro-brewerys such as Dogfish, American mass produced beers, taste like they were brewed by passing the ingredients through the urinary passage of a skunk.

Bottle. The pour was a sparkling clear reddish brown with an average sized (1-2 finger) off white fizzy head that was mostly diminishing and had fair lacing which somewhat stuck to the glass.

The aroma was of a toasted bread malt, a mild grassy hop and a earthy yeast with a hint of caramel.

The taste was moderately sweet with a light hint of caramel in the beginning and finished with a nice malty sweet flavor that had a mild hoppiness to it at the end. The flavor stayed with you for a decent amount of time allowing for the taste buds to fully enjoy all this brew has to offer.

Mouthfeel was light to medium in body and dry yet just a little oily in texture with a nice soft carbonation.

Overall the maltiness and mild sweetness of this brew works so wonderfully together. No wonder they call it the original. This just so happens to be the first Oktoberfest I ever tasted many years ago and in my opinion still is one of the best.

Bottle. Pours a deep amber orange colour with a good off white head. The aroma has lots of bready and sweet malts. with some caramel and toffee. The taste has sweet lightly toasted caramel malts with toffee and lots of bready biscuit flavor, with a dry finish.

Draught @ Zinnkeller, Helsinki. Copper-coloured with white head. Aroma of somewhat sweet malt and bread along with some nuts. Malt, nuts and some dark fruits in the flavour as well as some noble hops. Sweetish, malty finish with a hint of bitterness.
Tap. Pretty solid Oktoberfest - reddish/amber pour, biscuit & caramel malt on nose and taste. Flavorful and easy-drinking.
Roasted caramel in taste, great color. High drinkability. I wish there was more on the back end of this brew however. Overall pretty good brew that I would get again.

Dark golden/amber colour with medium sized dense white head. Aroma is wheat, grain, malt, slightly pepper, very small touch of spice. Taste is less full on wheaty as the aroma. Slight bitterness, but plenty of biscuit maltiness and bread/yeastiness. Slight prickle in the mouth. Medium bodied. Nice.
Bottle - Pours amber.  Choc caramel aroma with an earthy undertone.  Caramel malt flavour and a dry lingering finish.

Appearance: medium amber brown, pretty golden highlights, minimal light tan head, no lacing.  Aroma: malty, with notes of toast, honey, brown sugar, and definite caramel, a hint of leather.   Taste: toffee, caramel, brown sugar, toasted barley, a hint of roasted nuts, and a bit of mellow, earthy hops.   Finish: sweet malts linger gently, while the mellow hops combine with a surprising late zing to clean the palate.   Notes: 	Oktoberfest/Marzen is one of my favorite styles of beer, and this might be my favorite Oktoberfest beer.  Its at least as good as the Ayinger Oktoberfest, if not better.  Ill need to do a side-by-side to be sure.  The palate was chewy enough to complement the rich, sweet maltiness, while the bit of hops and that late hit of carbonation created a zesty finish that made me want more immediately.  The bottle was gone all too fast.

Location/Date:Duel Oktoberfest rating on October 5th, 2011 between Spaten and Hacker-Pschorr.E
Appearance: Pours a brownish orange semi clear color. 
Aroma: Aroma is of caramel, some hay.
Taste: Nearly no bitterness, lightly sweet and caramelly, nice amount of malt.
Palate:Light body, slightly slick, nearly flat carbonation. Quick finish.
Summary: I prefer this to the Spaten, and it is one of my prefered Oktoberfests, a style that has grown on me this season.
It is orange.  With an off white head.  Nothing different there.  Caramel and malts.  Pretty tasty and refreshing.

Pours a nice darker orange with a nice white head. The scent is nice and mellow with notes of toffee and some honey even. Tasted great, fairly malty like most Marzens but with a unique hop touch - very bitter and left a nice finish. Quite the impressionable brew here.
Bottle pour. Loads of sweet caramel malt and grassy hops. Poured out a dark amber color with nice off-white head. Taste was light and refreshing with caramel flavors and some light hops. Great.

Light amber colour, firm white head. Aroma of malts, caramel, slightly sweet. Light hops, touch of grass. Flavour sweetish, caramel, malts, some hops. Finish slightly hoppy, light citrus. Very drinkable. Great atmosphere ^_^
(Draught Maß @ Hackerfestzelt, Wiesn, München)
A fairly straight-up Oktoberfest beer. Not too distinguishable from the myriad of other german fest beers. Earthy hops spice, a bit of toasty caramel malts.  Decent brew.

bottle in a pint glass - pours caramel in color with white head that vanishes, but leaves some lacing.  Nose is faint caramel malts.  Aroma is is roasted malts with a hoppy finish.  Taste is sweet and ends hoppy.  Light bodied.  Oily feel.  Overall, very light, but yet somewhat bold in character.

330mL bottle.  Deep amber color, tall white head.  Heavy aroma of toasted malts, caramelized sugars.  Flavor characters of toffee malts, earthy / grass hops.  Tastes of earth.  Crisp and clean finish.  Very refreshing.  I could finish off a few of these...  PROST!

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2013 Re-rating, was a bit severe on first tasting, by the looks of it. Excellent drinkability for the strength and it has an extra dimension in its malt profile that the other Oktoberfest beers dont have.  
Previous rating on 25/09/11 = 6+3+7+3+13 = 3.2
50cl bottle. Pours an orangey-brown with a small head and very gentle bubbles. The nose has a smokey-maltiness and earthiness. The taste has more of the same as well as toffee and cake mixture. The palate is medium bodied with a smooth middle texture and a fairly clean finish. Overall, a nice alternative style for Oktoberfest.

(Draught at Hilpeä Hauki, 20110924) The beer poured amber and clear. Its head was medium sized and white. Aroma had malts, molasses and grass. Palate was medium bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were malts, molasses, caramell, grass and bitterness. Aftertaste had malts, molasses and bitterness. An easily drinkable beer with some nice edges.

Draught @ Gastropub Tuulensuu
Grainy and very malty aroma, actually rather typical to märzen. Flavour is sweetish and very malty with rather maltty and slightly hoppy finish. Becomes somewhat sticky with all the malt.

Draught @ Pullmans, Helsinki

Pours light orange with a small white head. Aroma has notes of malts, grassy hops and earthy notes. Taste is quite crisp with malts, slight hoppy notes and hints of pine and grass. Finish is slightly bitter and fruity with citrusy notes. Easy to drink, quite well balanced.

330ml bottle - $2.29 at Total Wine & More in Alpharetta, Georgia. Best Before: 6/12.

Appearance: Pours a clear, amber-tan body with a goodly-sized, white head.

Smell: Bready maltiness, very little implied sweetness, a floral-honey scent, albeit light, and a hint of old spice (not mens cologne).

Taste: Sweetish, bready maltiness. Flavors lighten, then, some thinned honey, floral, faintly spicy German hops and a small bit of bitterness. Hint of metallic yeastiness. Finishes fairly dry and clean.

Mouthfeel: Medium-light body. Medium-light carbonation. Just a hair thinner and flatter than Id care for.

Overall: An easy-drinking German brew, sure, though I found it to be a bit bland.
beautiful, amber orange, fast disappearing white head, limited lacing, smell medicine-ish (petro-carbo salve) and brass. Taste weak listerine, raw peanut, thin mouth

Bottle at home. Love me some Oktoberfest. Amber/orange pour, good cream head fades to nothing. Nose is sadly mediocre - lager grains and yeast. However the palate reveals a nice malt profile - biscuit, toffee, rich but somehow refreshing too. Lager bitter finish. Not bad, shame about the aroma.
Bottle from Bier Imperium, Vienna. Amber color with medium white head. Aroma of caramel, grass, some fruity notes. Taste, caramel, some vegetable, honey. sweet finish. Average.

Swing-top from Reichelt, fresh and best by 5/12.  Had this one a little warmer than usual.  Nose of sweet caramel, toast, lovely roasty and spicy (rye-inclusive?) malt.  Clear golden-amber pour with an ephemeral beige head.  Taste is medially bitter, sharp acidic caramel and toasty bread, has some unexpected higher-order alcohols that sting, especially in the nose.  A little warming, and slightly oily, medium body.  Nail polish remover aside, mild fruitiness an a tightly-spun lager profile, clean water and good enough for me, though Im going after other stuff from them if I ever get down to Munich in time for their world class piss-up.
Lots of lager yeast notes on the aroma and taste. Not very interesting. Strong lager. Nice appearance, amber.
Bottle poured into a stein. Aroma is hops, caramel, spice. Medium bodied, caramel malt, but not overtly sweet, dry finish, some spice, metallic. Nice Oktoberfest.

Tap.  Pale amber color with minimal head and effervescence.  Light molasses aroma.  Taste is slightly sweet, soapy, and flowery all balanced by a flash of sharp European hop bitterness than lingers about 20 seconds before it fades.  Medium palate.  One of the better Oktoberfest beers in a sea of many disappointing ones.

UPDATED: OCT 3, 2011 light-brown with a medium head. smell of malt. tastes malty and a bit spicy. some taste of banana in there. much more taste then the other munich oktoberfest beers. medium bitterness in the end.

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into clear cup.

Appearance: Clear coppery-amber with thin white head and light lacing.

Aroma: Caramel, cherry, noble hops and a touch of toast.

Taste: Malty mix of caramel, cherry and biscuit - the caramel is dominant but is surprisingly not sweet (as US caramel versions are). Ends with some light spicy noble hops.

Palate: Moderate carbonation, medium body, crisp and semi-dry finish.

Overall: Very drinkable and more than solid Marzen that shows how to focus on caramel without being cloying. US brewers - take note.

Already in the mood for great fall seasonal brew, already kicked started with pumpkin ale, not time to start with a good, authentic German Oktoberfest. Having some German blood in me, I make it mandatory every season and and at least a few times in other parts of the year to have a real, independent German brew. Seeing as I havent had this one yet, I picked it up.

Enjoy by date: 05/2012

Pours a nice light amber/copper.orange, enabling you to see through it. Very weak head, very little to no lacing.

Light aromas of grain(s), malt and grassiness, with faint tea-like scents. Pretty mediocre on the nose.

Grains, some tea-like and maybe light nuts land on the tongue. Malt is present, but less noticeable than it should be. Low carbonation. Body is rather thin.

Its probably the least Oktoberfest Marzen Ive had to date. Less malty, thin body and weak head and lacing hurts the credentials of this brew. its decent, but you can do a lot better. Many great German Oktoberfest brews out there, this one is a little less.

UPDATED: SEP 12, 2015 Draught @ Pub Kultainen Apina, Tampere.Pours a golden copper colour with a white lacy head. Aroma of sweet bready malts, nuts and honey. Flavour of sweet bready malts with mild fruitiness, grassy hops and honey. Medium bodied with high carbonation and a long finish of bready malts and honey. Nice one for a Märzen. 6-3-7-3-12 3.1, 2.9.2011.

Draught @ Gastropub Tuulensuu, Tampere, 12.9.2015. Pours a copper colour with a smooth white head. Bready, slightly sweet, toffeeish aroma. Flavour is really smooth with bready malts, dates, grassy bitterness, toffee and hay. Some mild spiciness even. Super good drinkability. One liter is not enough. 7-3-8-3-14 3.5
On tap at Frisco Grille.  Amber color with white head.  Malty aroma with some spice.  Malty flavor with spice and slight hop finish.

One of the best Oktoberfest beers out there.  I think second, only to Spaten.  Golden amber in color, white head, aroma of fruits, nuts, little alcohol.  Smooth tasting brew, caramel, hints of honey, balanced with hops.  Spicy flavor with a sweet finish.
Clear golden with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, fruity and grainy. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Dry and light bitter finish. 250811
Bottle. Dark golden/brown with medium off-white head. Flavour is malt, fruit, caramel, hops, bread, little sweet and a little bitter.

Bottle bought in Tengelmann supermarket in Bavaria. Its a deep honey-brown with honey and hops aromas, then a roast malty body with burnt toffee, hints of roast oranges and nuts and then a dryish and gently bitter finish. A decent example of the style.

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2014 On Tap @ Mr. Dunderbaks, Sarasota Square Mall (in 1983).  Alongside Spaten Optimator, this is the 2nd best beer i have ever tasted (at the time).
Ive only had it on tap, but im sure its very good in the bottle as well. Malty, sweet, smooth, Bavarian goodness! Highly recommended,

Eindeutig eins der besseren Oktoberfestbiere. Süffig ist es natärlich, wie bei Bieren dieser Sorte kaum anders zu erwarten. Eine gut dosierte Herbe schwingt von Anfang bis Ende mit, ein malziger Unterton ist durchaus in einigen Teilen zu erschmecken. Ein wenig fehlt der Pepp jedoch schon, ich vermisse einen ausgereifteres Aroma. Irgendwie fällt mir zu diesem Bier das Wort "kernig" ein. 	 
Test vom 20.10.2005, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 6,10,11,10,14,9 - 9,55

Bottle at Long Lake left by someone l33t.  Much better than the Otter Creek Oktoberfest, which I had right before this.   Rich sweet malts and caramel, typical of the style... however a noticable amount of hops are a nice touch you dont always see.

Poured a beautiful light amber with a foamy little head.  Aroma of caramelized pale malt, some light toast, and a touch of cereal.  Taste wasnt too far off--initially hits with a crisp and vibrant not-too-bitter grass hop bitterness, followed quickly by toast, caramel malt, light touch of cereal, very light bitterness at the end.  A crisp, semi-dry fine example of a Marzen.

Reviewed from notes.

Poured into a pilsner glass. Color is a moderate brown-bronze with a good white head. Nose is toasted malt with some caramel and toffee plus a slight nutty character. Taste is toasted bread with a bit of caramel. Slightly sweet with just a touch of bitterness. Light-to-medium body with nice carbonation. Drinkability is pretty good and this is one of my more-preferred German marzens.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-13-2010
Not bad, pleasantly surprised by this one. Poured from bottle, nice amber color.

5 Oct 2010, bottle. light amber colour crystal clear w/ no bubbles. nutty and grainy aromas. a little bready w/ some alcohol aroma as well as caramel. med body w/ just the faintest bit of carbonation and some tiny bit of wateriness. nutty wheat flavours w/ some caramel notes. nothing special. very quiet. how is this so popular?

Listed as Hacker Pschorr Original Oktoberfest. Pours with a completely clear orange to light bronze hued body (harvest colors) with a small off-white head. Aromas are toasty, bready, maple, melanoidins, lightly grassy and grainy with a hint of vanilla. Aroma is all about the malt. Clean, no yeast presence, no hops. Nice malt complexities. Flavors are malt accentuated and leans sweet in flavor, but not cloying. Crisp finish. No esters. Melanoidins and toasted grain. Possibly a hint of hops. A touch warming for a marzen. Medium bodied and well attenuated with a crisp finish. Medium to lively carbonation with a lingering malt character.

It looks like a typical okt fest beer, nothing to set it apart. Big head and great lacing.

The aroma is all sweet malts cant get anything specific or uniquie from it.

The taste is ok, just sweet throughout. This okt fest is the budligt of marzens, sadly, nothing special here. Moutfeel bad but you can crush it.
what a lovely drop! nuttiness and herbs for start followed by pleasant caramel finishing witha very smooth yet refreshing  floral bitterness. I definately recommend giving this a try!

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2016 12 fluid ounce bottle, produced on 07/09.

Pours with a 3 finger head into my mug with an amber body. There is a slight bit of foam that resides on top of the liquid that never dissipates.

Smell is a bit subdued for a typical Maerzen, with a nice hop and malt balance. The malts have that typical sweet, nutty maltiness, though it is a bit faint.

The mouth feel is smooth and a bit under carbonated. Intense Oktoberfest flavor though. I love the taste of this, perfect sweet and nutty, slightly roasty malt taste, amazing hop balance, just a highly quaffable beer. Not the most robust version of this style out there, but in terms of taste, it is the standard flavor of Oktoberfest.

Overall it is a solid Oktoberfest, and like all examples of the style it has its strengths and weaknesses.

RERATE
This has been a perennial oktoberfest for me over the years, the ever so slightly clearer/lighter look has always appealed. This is my first and last bottle of this year (presumably) Pours a very clear amber color. Frothy head. Aroma is thick with bready malt flavors, smells worty almost, just a touch of earthy hops. Flavor is again worty, but with a crisp low bitterness that just cuts through, it is mildly nutty, though the malt character is visceral it isnt sweet at all, but fairly dry. The hops in the flavor bring more of an herbel marmalade feel, the body is not heavy and very drinkable. This proves again and again despite me drinking it 6 months too late it is everything a dark oktoberfest should be.
Not a bad Octoberfest, has a decent breadiness to it, just sort of bland compared to the great ones.

A: The pour is a deep, dark copper color with a couple of fingers worth of off-white head.

S: Lots of sweet and bready malts to begin with. Earthy hop notes along with a slight spice quality. I get nutmeg and all-spice for the most part, and there is a fair amount of yeast.

T: The bread and hops are at the forefront. Semi-sweet malts along with floral and earthy hops. The bitterness is quite light, but a lot of the same spices that the nose had.

M: Medium in body with a lively carbonation to it. Really refreshing, actually.

D: Another top German tick, and its on the list with good reason. I liked this one quite a lot and will make sure to pick some up each year.
Great beer.Aroma sweet and malty and taste even better malt is king in this beer.I could drink this beer year round easy.
Bottle. Brownish, amber color. Nice head. Toffe malt flavor, just the right amount of bitter and hops. Good and maltly aroma. Love this beer.

Pours a nice copper color.  Thin white head that dissipates quickly.  Mile aroma of wheat bread and caramel.  Typical caramel malt flavor with a slightly metallic aftertaste.  A decent marzen, but nothing to write home about.

This pours a crystal clear bronze-type color.  Aroma is of sweet cereal grains, slight caramel malts and not much else.  The flavor is rather light, a bit fruity, slightly grainy, and sweet.  Pretty simple.

23/10 Our guests brought a 2 l fliptop bottle of this in autumn. 6.0% ABV. It poured darker golden body with medium sized head that went down fast. Nice herbal hop aroma, slightly malty. Quite bitter flavor, lot of herbal and typical spicy hops that remind of cardboard and usually is used in dry german pilsners. A bit of bready malt present as well, but nothing more. Medium in body with longer, bitter herbal hop finish. Fine for a quench thirsting, not even generally bad, but hardly anything special, no matter I was in mood for drinking anything on the given day.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2013 Bottle. Caramel with a small but thick light beige head. Aroma of caramel, nuts, toast. Taste has mouthcoating caramel without as much sweetness as that suggests. Nuts, drying hops hint at spice. A fat, malty lager that is easily as good as it needs to be but doesnt really try to be more. [3.4] A pervasive and depressing cardboard note in this one, 2.8. Just seems cheap and dreary. Averaging score.

500ml bottle. Ruby red in colour with a deep thick dirty white foam pillow. Caramel aroma that is pleasnat. Smooth and easy to drink with little flavour. Bitternes is slight and kicks in at the finish.

Rich amber/cider color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of malt, caramel, some toffee, & spice; Flavor of slight roasted sweet malt, caramel, hops, and light fruit; Nicely balanced; Overall, pretty good.

Caramel colored pour, minimal bubbly head. Aroma and flavor both marked with sweet malt, bread, biscuit, and a touch of raisin. Palate is light and crisp, very drinkable and refreshing for a malt based brew. Nice stuff.
Bottle.  Poured in a pint.  Sampled in a fall tasting I hosted for friends.  Pours light copper in color with a pure white head.  Light caramel aroma with a touch of hops.  Smooth and easy drinking.

Bottle 50cl. A clear amber beer with good head and carbonation. Smell is on lager yeast with grassy notes. Aroma is on caramel notes (DMS ?) slightly vegetal, medium malty and sweet, spicy hops at the finish. A bit classic Oktoberfest, in the average with honey notes and slightly metallic finish.

Dark yellow - cream colored head.  Mostly a malt aroma - perhaps a bit sweet.  Taste is sweet, roasted malt with a bit of a light fruit taste going on.  Very little bitterness, with the finish being more malt.  A good Oktoberfest for those that dont like a lot of hops flavor.

Enjoyed with Uncle Steve and Uncle Tom, Brian the Beer Pimp and the Immortal Drbayern.  Poured a dark yellow with a lacy white head.  There was a malty aroma.  The taste was a light malt, with some bite to the taste.  I did not find much of an aftertaste and that lowered the score
UPDATED: JUN 16, 2012 Bottle from Peckhams. Corn & banana aroma. Medium brown colour. Sweet vegetable and banana flavour. Very nice bottle. Good, not great.

Another one of the märzen versions of oktoberfestbiers from the Munich brewers.   After having the wiesn beer at the fest, its quite a change-up to go to this.   Deep copper-red color with a big light beige head.   Bread crust, caramel, and toasty malt aroma.   The flavor has a rich toasty and darker melanoidin character with a touch of caramel sweetness.   Hops are mellow.   Pretty clean and drinkable but a but too sweet to be drunk in quantity, which is after all why they moved away from this style at the festival.
On tap.  Pours a slightly cloudy brown with little head.  Goes down very smoothly without a lot of carbonation to get in the way.  Light hops and stronger malt flavor.  Excellent, overall.
18th May 2006  Warning! Early amateur rating! Juicy rich amber lager with a subtle fruit tone. Slightly bitter but very nice.
500 ml bottle a amber colored beer with a white head aroma malts spices and hops taste malts spices and bitter hops

Bottled 2,0L, ABV 6%. Golden fraught yellow color. Discreet bubbly aspect with a nice and solid bulky head. Alcoholic aroma with notes of dried cereals, malty, very hoppines. Little unbalanced body, too much malty and overbanding bitter/alcoholic final.

Deep copper tone in the glass.  aroma is light toasted notes with some sweet caramelized sugar.  mouthfeel is medium, some intense sweet caramel maltiness greets my tongue, some light dewiness and some honeysuckle yeastiness also makes its way through.  Nice, light, and sweet maltiness, pretty tasty

500 ml flip-top bottle in Germany. Darkish walnut amber body, creamy large off-white head. Grainy perfume hops come through in the aroma. Flavor has more of a sweet husky malt with the same type of light perfumy hops covered by grain. Pretty good overall.
Golden amber color with min. Head. Malty, metallic nose. Med bodied palate has some saccharine sweetness on the finish. Not much else
500ml bottle.  Pours dark brown with a very little head.  Aroma is is caramel malt with some yeast.  Starts with some caramel malt.  Hint of apples on the finish.  Dry finish.
Amber color with foamy white head.  Bready aroma.  Taste is spicy, fresh baked bread, toasted malt, yeast, and caramel.  Nice balancing bitterness.  Medium body, rich and malty.  A great Marzen!

Poured pale copper with barely any head.  Spots of lace.  The aroma was lots of malt, spice and metal.  The flavor was sweet malts, a touch of yeast and some spice.  A touch of metal snuck through.  Thin and easy drinking.
Pours amber-brown with tan head and some lacing.  Pleasant notes of malt and hops.  Well balanced taste.
Caramel malt. Decent hop presence. Very clean crisp taste.  Probably my favorite octoberfest.  On tap at wet whistle in abington pa.

Bottle leftover from my Oktoberfest party.  Pours a rich leather coloration with small soapy head.  Not much aroma but taste is pure caramel malt with slight bitterness and dry on the finish.  Maybe some bread and basement feel to it with lively enough carbonation.

Bottle: Pours a nice golden amber, with a modest white head. Aroma is of a nice caramelized malt. Typical german hop flavors here, with a decent caramelized maltiness, with a touch of bitterness as well at the end. Probably my favorite of the big 6
On tap. Smooth and well balanced. Easy to drink. Quite hoppy for the style.

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2011 In bottle in Munich; good solid Oktoberfest Marzen. I think I still like Ayinger better, but this (and Paulaner) are very good, very easy drinking beers ... wish I could get at home. UPDATED 10/31; on tap. Pours nice golden auburn color. Aroma - hoppy with a little sweetness. Taste very,, very good. Still think Ayinger is a touch better (though sweeter) but a good marzen none the list

On tap at the Bulldog Saint Paul. Good amber/orange color with a light beige head. The malts have that Hacker-Pschorr quality . . . theres something thats both familiar, and thus attractive, but also off-putting about it . . . seems kind of "macro-esque" to me, but maybe Im being too picky. This is a bit more malty and caramlesque than I expected -- more bold, I suppose -- which is a pleasant surprise, though for some palates I think this beer might be cloying. For me, its a nice session beer; its tasty enough, but rather one-dimensional when all is said and done.
Very dark amber body with small foamy head. I gotta be honest and say I cant pick out any specific flavors, but I enjoyed it.

12oz bottle from Whole Foods Los Altos.  Great appearance: deep orange color with a large lasting off-white foam cap.  The aroma is nice for the style with loads of Munich malt and a slight earthy German hop character.  The flavor is great for the style as well.  Caramel and Munich malts, slightly sweet with cereal grains and nice crisp German hops.  Medium-bodied with average carbonation.  Really good for the style.
Malty aroma, with medium-dark amber color. Very effervescent. Quickly disappearing head. Rolls well across the palate. Sweet finish.
Amber with puffy head. Smells and tastes malty, like typical oktoberfest, but ends up being a little weak. Not bad, but not great either.
nice copper hue with short lived head, low carbonation, nice malt backbone that dominates what hops are there, aroma of caramel, bread, and basement - a decent marzen
UPDATED: OCT 3, 2014 a solid if unspectacular example of the style.  nice toasted malt backbone and hop balance, just nothing that stands out.

(bottle)  I had this beer many an Oktoberfest season and look forward to its release every year.  This particular sample did not seem quite as good as prior releases.  However, this remains my favorite of the traditional German Oktoberfest beers.

pours a deep gold w/ a small off-white head.  clear, and good carbonation.  Getting som toasted bread, and caramel on the nose.  No hints of hops.  Medium body, good carbonation.  Smooth.  Slight hop bitterness in the finish. Tasting nicely toasted malts, bready, and caramel followed by a small a small amount of hop bitterness.  Im liking this beer.
Draft @ Monster Bs. Served in a pint glass. This is a nice malt-heavy Oktoberfest with a crisp hop pairing. Champagne, green pear notes. Very good session beer.

Pours a clear copper with a small white head. It has a fresh malty aroma. The taste is of gently roasted malt with a mild, peppery hop taste. It had a slightly off aftertaste near the end of my glass, but its all good.

Bottle.  Pours a beautiful amber color with a rich white head.  One sniff and I couldnt wait to put this in my mouth!  Delicious note of sweet bubblegum and banana mixed in with caramel and straw.  The taste?  Where have you been all these Octobers?!  A superbly balanced and complex marzen with a medium sweetness that brings all those smells directly to your tongue.  It was delicious it was refreshing it was, in a word, awesome.  This is easily the best Oktoberfest beer Ive tried to date. This would be a great transition beer for warm fall or spring days.  I would absolutely recommend this beer to anyone that is wondering what to drink this Oktoberfest!
50cl swing-top bottle bought in Düsseldorf.  Pours golden amber with a frothing cream head that quickly disappears; slightly sweet and spicy flavour; some dry malts to finish. OK but nothing more.

On Draft at Munich Haus. Taps a very nice dark amber color with a large beige, but quickly diminishing head. ok, lacing. Aroma is fairly faint malt and spice, some earthiness. Flavor is good, nice and malty sweetness the whole way through, but dominated by a lot of weird dry hoppy astringency followed by a surprising alcoholic kick. Medium, light mouth-feel, which works to its advantage. (brewed with spring water) This is a very enjoyable beer, Oktoberfest is not my style of choice, but this is a good one on tap,

500 ml swingtop bottle, from Rewe Getränkemarkt, Erding. ABV is 5.8%. Deep golden to amber colour, moderate head, slightly off-white.  Moderate aroma of grassy and herbal hops, a hint of caramel. The flavour is fairly malty with hints of caramel, notes of grassy and herbal hops again. Spritzy mouthfeel. A decent Märzen this one.

This poured a medium orange to amber color with an off white head. Aroma was of slightly toasted caramel malt and some grassy notes. Flavor was a bit sweet and toasted, but fairly bland and a bit dusty attic and old hops notes.

Beer seems crystal clear brownish orange with minimal head and what was there did not last long. Aroma is malty with some spice very light and crisp. Dry light flavor with mildly bitter caramel malts, grass, elements of orange and pepper. Very easy drinking

Much lighter than I anticipated, being an octoberfest.  This is more like a Pilsner with a little bit of depth to me.  Kind of reminds me a lot of a Amstel Light.  Great carbonation, slightly off white head.  Finishes very clean.  Tasty and very sessionable.

Amazingly smooth. Great color. Good flavor. It was difficult to find a flaw in this beer especially considering the style. Maybe, just maybe its a bit too sweet. But Im hardly complaining. This is good beer.

Bottle. Very slightly hazed amber with a small white head that fades a bit leaving some lace throughout the session. Nose is cereal, nuts, toast, caramel, light roast. Flavor is slightly sweet, a little bitterness, some nuts, a little new plastic.
UPDATED: APR 4, 2016 Solid Oktoberfest/Marzen. Nice layer of sweetness and caramel to the beer. Serving: Bottle
Tap at the Gingerman Fort Worth.  Dark orange pour with an off-white head.  Aroma is fruit, spice, hops, and a little floral.  Taste is biscuit, orange, lemon, brown sugar, sap.  Dry finish.

Reddish pour, some white head.  Some visible carbonation.  Aroma of caramel, apple juice, some bread and crackers.  Flavor is lightly fruity, lots of crackers and bread, slight leafy hopiness.  Mouthfeel is about perfect.  Light to medium bodied, good carbonation.  It goes down so smooth.  Really nice drinking beer.  Pretty nice to drink on an almost fall night.
