Tap at Gman FW provided by Fratto. Clear amber orange color. Light white ring of head. Quite the fruity smell! Im picking up lots of sweet berry and grape. Plenty of sugar on the nose. Taste is also fairly fruity, like grape juice. Lightly bitter but sweet. Interesting.
On tap at Pour House at Grand Central, Tampa, FL. Amber body with German hops, malt and light barnyard notes that grew rather taxing while progressing through the beer.

Pours a clean translucent copper orange with a one finger fizzy offwhite head. Nose is sweet earthy malt, caramelly, some corn, leafy and herbal hop profile, some raisin and bubblegum. Flavor is odd, sweet and nutty malt profile, some bubblegum, mildly spicy, leafy hops. Palate shows a low bitterness and a crisp mouthfeel.

Fliptop bottle from "KülönlegesSörökBoltja", Bp.
Shows a clear amber coloured pour with a medium, but laceing head on top.
Smell of caramell and grass.
It startslight crisp on the tongue with a smooth and slick moutfeel, the taste is toasty/toffee-liked.
The middle has caramell, spicy/grassy hops beside some yeasty undertones  within, the pleasantly balanced finish brings a spicy bitterness along, which drains the palate and remain in a good aftertaste.
Good drinkable and medium bodied, overall well enjoyable.

[Bottle] Pours a deep amber color with a thin off-white head. Notes of caramel and light hopping in the aroma. The taste is similar, with biscuits, grain and caramel throughout. Average mouthfeel and carbonation. Lingering sweet malt finish. There is nothing wrong with this beer, but there was little complexity here. A tad boring actually.

500ml bottle - 

Aroma - nutty/caramel base malts, light apple aroma coming around about mid-glass too.  

Appearance - bright amber body, 1" off-white head, medium retention

Taste - solidly built o-fest and I think that the extra few months have done it well.  Sweetness seemed high, but it worked with the fruity/caramel angle of the beer and light on any hop notes.  Finish is a bit bready.

Palate - medium bodied, carbonation kept well in check...nothing out of character for this style.

Overall - a really nice example and rivals probably one of my favorite O-fest styles in Kostritzer.  Id get again for sure.  Nice price too.
Orange-red, off white head.  Aroma is very grainy, candy, toast.  Taste is caramel, sweet, grain, toasty dryness.

Original Oktoberfest Amber Marzen--1998 16.9 oz. Bottle.  5.50% ABV.  (3.0 / 5.0)  Light clear amber color.  No yeast profile.  No hop profile.  Silky smooth slightly sweet light malt body.  Classic German Marzen mouthfeel and flavor.  Very different from NW ale style.  Clean finish.  Sampled 3/13/1999.

Original Oktoberfest Amber Marzen--1999 16.9 oz. Bottle.  5.50% ABV.  (3.25 / 5.0)  Clear bright copper color.  Big head-light lace.  Light malty front.  Light toasted caramel body with light fruit sweet flavor based on smooth doughy malt.  Clean end.  Oktoberfest but bland.  Sampled 10/10/1999.

Original Oktoberfest Amber Marzen--1999 12 oz. Bottle.  5.50% ABV.  (3.0 / 5.0)  Very clear thin amber golden color.  Smooth but rather bland.  Light toasted caramel fruit body with malty doughy base.  Clean easy finish.  Oktoberfest Lite.  Sampled 10/9/1999.

Original Oktoberfest--2000 16 oz. Bottle.  5.80% ABV.  (4.25 / 5.0)  Clear rich copper amber color.  Rich toasted fruit malt front.  Crisp Oktoberfest body with tangy malty taste.  Mild sweetness and slightly spicy.  Classic flavor.  Finishes spicy and malty.  Reminds me of Thomas Kemper Oktoberfest.  Sampled 9/30/2000.

Hacker-Pschorr Original Oktoberfest--2004 16.9 oz. Bottle.  5.80% ABV.  20 IBUs?  (4.25 / 5.0)  Mild lace head.  Clear bright thin dark amber color.  Malty mild floral fruit hop front.  Smooth crisp malty mild toasted caramel apple cherry fruit body.  Mild tangy citrus hop dry sweet end.  No stank.  Festy!  Sampled 9/29/2004.

Original Oktoberfest Amber Marzen--2007 16.9 oz. Bottle.  5.80% ABV.  20 IBUs?  (4.25 / 5.0)  Rich lacy head.  Clear bright thin dark amber color.  Malty mild fruit hop front.  Smooth creamy rich mellow caramel breadfruit mild sweet malty Bavarian body.  Smooth crisp mild hop lingering creamy end.  Sampled 7/26/2007.

Continues Improvement In Shipping Quality Retention.

A- Transparent caramel color that doesnt produce much of a head and fades quickly to a thin collar. Little lacing is left behind in the glass. Bubbles can be seen rising to the top. Decent for the style. Doesnt appear watered down.

S- Nose is mild and consists of caramel malt, pale malt, and hops. I cant really identify what type of hops...but they are definately there.

T- Much like the smell initial flavor of caramel and German pale malt with a touch of hoppy flavor overtone. The finish is much like the initial flavor but the hops come out just a wee bit more. Nothing lingers which makes you want more.

P- Nice lightweight lager mouthfeel with medium carbonation. Goes down really easy. Not too thin.

O- This is another good O-fest beer. Very drinkable and good. Nothing particularly special but I was happy to finally try an O-fest made in Germany.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-12-2008 02:15:01

Pours medium amber with a 1 finger, creamy white head that has decent retention. Sweet and grainy, floral, mineral and ceral. Medium bodied, somewhat slick palate with a light to medium carbonation. Pretty good Marzen.
On tap at the Castle on King.  Reddish, with little head.  Fairly light and easy drinking, not quite as much flavour as I expected, but nicely balanced.

Bottle from Beers of Europe. Mahogany coloured ale with a white head that swiftly disappears. Aromas of caramel, nuts, dark fruits, baked apple. Flavours of crisp red apples, toffee, caramel, malts. Quite sweet. Definately has an autumnal feel about it. Sweet, malty finish. Quite pleasant.

0,5 literes üvegből kóstolva. Érlelt konyak színű ital, mely alig habosodik és ez a hab is hamar elszáll. Buborékok szinte egyáltalán nincsenek. Illata erősen és kellemesen malátás, enyhén füstös. Ízében is nagyon dinamikusan jelentkezik a malátás gabona íz, de mellette a komló is dominál rendesen.

500 ml bottle. From Germany (beerangel.com).
Clear mahogany colour with small white head.
Mild malty aroma with nuts and wood.
Mild malty flavour. Balanced.
Clear amber-rust color with no head. Nutty pumpernickel, yeasty sweetbread aromas. medium body. Thin lagered caramel malt flavors with some mineral, sweetbread.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Always enjoy fest beers but this seems to be the best Ive had.  Smooth texture with autumnal flavors and finishes sweet.  Great fall beer.

Pours clear deep amber with a thin fading beige head. Aroma of caramel, apple, apricot, bready buttery biscuity malt. Taste is sweet and roasty with a good balance. Fuller bodied than most Marzens Ive had. I am not a huge fan of this style but this beer is more complex than most.

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2013 Tap @ cloverleaf. Golden pour with white head. Spices,  german hops and yeast effects, plus malty flavor notes and aroma, make for a decent beer that is in a word boring.

Edit, my favorite Oktoberfest.
The beer tastes so smooth and pure in the German tradition. It is slightly sweet and malty with a ruby amber color.

Bottle. Light malt aromas of dark bread and cereal, light herbs for the hops, with toffee, honey and a hint of cola in the background. Head is fizzy, white with no lacing and is fully diminishing. Color is sparkling clear light brown. Flavor starts lightly sweet and acidic, then finishes the same way. Palate is light to medium, watery with a lively carbonation. Pretty light all around, but just about everything an Oktoberfest is supposed to be, this is.

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2011 (Draught at Hollerbachs in Sanford FL, 5.8%)

carmely hoppy balanced, nothing impressive but nothing bad, straight-forward.

(rerate)
Appearance is amber with a thin head, medium body, and medium carbonation.
Flavor is full of toffee and caramel. There is a definite note of caramelization, like is typical from decoction mashing, in which grains are pulled from the mash and simmered over high heat before being stirred back in. Yeast and alcohol esters are moderate. Hop flavor, hop bitterness, and minerality are all very muted.
Overall, this beers focus is all about caramelized malt, which is my favorite aspect of traditional Oktoberfest beers.

Original Octoberfest Bottle. Pours a dep nutty brown color with a small white head. Nose is light caramel and is bready with a light nut note. Palate is full with a light syrup but not cloying. Flavors or light bready dough notes and some nut hints in the finish.
Notes of apple or cherry and biscuity malt and hops in the nose. Nice long lasting bitter finish. Well balanced.

Bottle with friends. Pours a burnt copper in color with a medium size off white head. Aroma is bready  and malty. Flavors of toasted malt, honey, and a hint of fruit back up the minor hop presence in the finish.

Tap at Rhino, served in HS dimpled mug. Sweet, fine creamy serve, not too chilled - perfect. Unusual grapey & cola/sasparilla rootsy flavors - rolls over the palate kind of fruity with a spice note, insanely quaffable and surprisingly tasty. Well worth the diversion.

12 oz bottle. Pours a dark amber with a big, off white, short lived head. Lively carbonation. The best quality of the beer is its nice aroma of caramel malts, perfume hops and some dough. The flavor is similar to aroma, but much weaker. Finish is short and unremarkable. The body is medium and crisp. OK Octoberfest but there are much better choices.
0,5 liter beugelfles. Heerlijk oktober feest bier. Meerdere keren dit gedronken maar deze is toch wel erg goed. Hoe zou ze smaken in een 2 liter glas.
Bottle from Bier-Spezialitäten-Laden, Berlin. Dark amber with a foamy head. Malty aroma. Some bread, not much bitterness, some sweetness lingering. Hints of earth and biscuit. Drinkable.

Poured amber/orange color, with 2 finger white head that quickly dissapated. Aroma = heavier toasted bread notes, smells malt forward, but also seems more balanced than most o-fests i have had, as there is a bit of floral hops. Taste - well balanced with nice sweet malty, nutty, toasted bread, just a touch bitter, but none of them necessarily dominating. Extremely easy drinking beer. mouthfeel is thin-medium.

Overall this is a great version of an Oktoberfest beer, That I could kill several pints of easily. I will gladly buy this one again.

Bottle  Pours a clear amber with a big off white head.  The head is froathy and deminishes quickly.  Laces nicely.  Has a good aroma of caramel malts, and a touch of grain.  Hasan okay carbonation.  The flavor is okay.  Has some malts and grains like the aroma.  Clean and smooth.  Has a light to medium body.  Has an airy texture if you can understand that.  I know what I mean but cant really describe it.  Has a decent finish and an okay aftertaste.

Amber bodied with a s skull colored head. Big caramel sweet malty aroma. Flavor is complementary to the aroma, malt up front some herbal hoppiness. Perfect, I guess, for what it is. Certainly one of the better Octoberfests I have tried.

Amber clear pour with a ever so slight off white head that is quick to disappear. It is clear with slight carbonation. There is a grainy malt smoke flavor on nose for this light bodied marzen. There is a slight crisp bitterness on mouth along with a soft malt taste.

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2010 Clear darker orange pour white head malty sweet caramel aroma ..... sweet lightly roasted caramel taste with a light bitter finish ... simple and refreshing nice malt flavor one of my fav oktobers

reminded me of Oktoberfest in Munchen.
The apperance had Reddish tint, very clear in fact. The taste was better than expected. My overall impression was: the beer was very good; the alcohol was very well hidden and it very drinkable.
tap @ chanceys.  clear dark orange, thin whispy head. nose of sweat malts, lots of fruits and slightly yeasty. goes down well, tastes as sweet as it smells. could drink all day.

On tap:

A rich deep amber-orange with a large puffy off white cap.

Aromas are on the mark: Rich toasty breadiness wet hay and some sweet mustiness.

Medium bodied, rich whack of toasty-sweet malts in the front ( decoction mashed?), nice herbal hop balance sits back a bit profiling the malts. The highlight of the drink is the middle which features a grat malt complexity...then it goes lightly dry and slightly herbal-bitter in the finish.

Great stuff. If youre a lager drinker this is pretty much bottled sex.

500ml bottle (BeerAngel) - stolen off Jarkko at work - thanks!
Rich reddy brown, healthy head. At first a slightly plasticky aroma, but as it warms the malts fill out, and it becomes quite grainy eventually. Pleasant carbonation, refreshing palate. Taste initially a bit metallic. As it warms, again, the softer malts come through and its a pleasantly husky graininess that youre left with. Half a litre disappeared very quickly.
12 oz. bottle.  Pours a beautiful amber / mahogany with off white head.  Smells of caramel malts, sweet yeast.  Tastes of roasty caramel, clean finish.  Great Marzen.

On tap. Pours a medium clear golden brown with a small off white head. Aroma is malty, toasty, nutty and pretty sweet caramel sugary. Flavor is much of the same, very sweet and caramel, toasty. Nice flavorful and refreshing roundness to the mouth feel, but refreshing as an oktoberfest marzen should be. Nice spicy hop character in the finish that gives a good balance. Nice creamy body and a soft carbonation makes for a mellow and refreshing beer.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2009 12oz bottle drank 5 months after the born-on date, so the freshness is a tad suspect.  Orange-brown color with a respectable head.  CO2 bubbles solidly flowing inside.  Sweet mellow malt aroma.  Soft and creamy and displaying a lot of lager yeast notes, this is certainly on the mellow, maltier side of Oktoberfests.  Very subdued hops, adding an initial crispness and mild spicy characteristic to the caramel sweet golden malt.  A pretty aweome session beer, though not quite as complex as most Stateside microbrewery versions.
Dated 03/09: Weak malt aroma with some cherries. Clear amber, medium vanishing head. Tastes cheap and stale. Malt, then cherries. It improves with warming, but remains drab. Decently refreshing.

On tap at Ginger Man.  Pours a dark, reddish amber with a thin, off-white head.  Nose is weak and bread was about all that was noticeable.  Taste was of yeast, nut, bread and spice.  Mouthfeel was watery with a slight bitterness.

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2009 Bottle. 
Lovely light amber color, with a good, thick slightly amber-tinted head. Fabulous nose: very malty, slightly sweet, slightly strong and fruity aroma. Decent malt flavor, slightly strong, a touch of sweetness reminiscent of a pale bock, but much less sweet, much dryer. A bit nutty. Pretty good hops, well balanced. Medium carbonation and body. Slightly dry, hoppy finish that does not quite pack enough punch. A very good beer, the best of the Oktoberfests in Munich, I think.
UPDATED: SEP 11, 2014 Sweet roasty aroma. Clear amber color that pours a great, but quickly dissipating head. Sweet flavors of malt, light hints of fruit, and perfect hop balance. not bad

Intense malty fig nose, Orangey brown color, medium long lasting soapy head.  Perfectly balanced rich caramel maltiness and restrained, but effective hop bitterness.  Medium to high carbonation, medium body, rich mouth feel, bright fruity malty finish.  All around one of the best Oktoberfest beers, has great balance, depth of flavor--well crafted.
This is a pretty solid Oktoberfest, a step above what I had so far in the States, not as thin...nice malty flavor, fruits, caramel, goes down smooth, very drinkable..
Amber pour with a white head. Aroma of caramel malt, toasted malt, and sweetness. Taste is crisp, sweet, caramel, smooth. Nice aftertaste.
Bottle. High creamy and lasting white head. Clear dark brown body. Malty caramel nut butter aroma. Relatively bitter barley malt caramel flavor with a long afterastee.

Sampled at Lundeens Brew Ha-Ha 2009. Pours a clear amber-orange color with a small, dense, white head. Aroma has an light amount of toasted malt with an average amount  caramel, straw, hay and apple notes. Flavor has a strong grainy presence, grassy, light caramel and some metallic tastes. Medium body and a pretty creamy texture which made the beer feel pretty good. Overall an okay oktoberfest but still misses the mark a bit.

Fliptop from Arden Wines. Pours brilliant copper with a receding billow of suds. Beeswax, leather, oily garden hop aroma with some cake-like sweetness and almond. Soapy pinecone hop, chewed pencil, lingering bread and honey, lick of Nutella. CHURCH END. Supped this with some greasy late night nibbles, which really didnt work and killed the carbonation and flavour to some extent. A shame because its a fine and distinctive Oktoberfest with a richer, breadier malt profile than most. Filtered, bottled or from the wood, HP are quality.

12 ounce bottle from Beer Run in Charlottesville, VA. Pours a Pours a clear brown tinted copper color with a thin frothy offwhite head. Fair head retention and lacing. Aroma of toasted grains, raisin, citrus, caramel. Very, very faint hoppy note. Taste is caramel and toasted malts, some raisins. Slight bready. Softly carbonated, medium bodied. Good beer.

The aroma is earthy smell, cereal grains, malts, caramel, fruit, prunes.  The appearance is the reddish/orange, true to the Oktoberfest style.  The flavor is caramel, malts, brown sugar, bread.   The finish is a light hop bittering.  Medium mouthfeel.  Not great, but very drinkable.
Bottle. Dark copper color. Smells strongly of malt. Very rich and malty tasting. Very good. Somewhat spicy flavor.
Good example of the style, but not the greatest.  Everything youd expect from your run of the mill marzen.  Uber drinkable on a hot day!
Had on tap at Delaware Saengerbund Oktoberfest. Nice color, big head, Aroma and flavor were both good, but nothing special, sweet and malty. VERY drinkable, crushed a liter of it quick.

Very good oktoberfest. Much lighter and lighter bodied then other offerings. This one doesnt have that sticky mouthful you get in so many other oktoberfests. Easy drinking and finished pretty dry. I would say its alittle watery but not in a bad way. Still has some nice flavor.
Nice aroma of caramel malt with a touch of hops.  Flavor is caramel malt, bread and a dry slightly bitter finish. Not bad.
Pours a nice clear light amber with a thin white head. Aroma was a little sweet, a little malty with some light hop notes. Flavor was similar. Easy drinker, nothing spectacular.

poured a nice amber and clear with short lasting off-white head. Caramel malt nose.  Full on the tongue although carbonation also leaves an impression, sweet but with a bit of hop bitterness to balance.  Nothing great but a clean tasting clean finishing brew.  Something you could kick back and drink while chatting with friends.
Clear amber of color with a white head. An aroma of malt and toffee. A flavor of malt, sweets, toffee and weak bitterness.

Poured a metallic brown with a medium white foamy head.  Nice malty aroma with hints of yeast, wheat, and a little citrus.  Slightly watery, but some good caramel malt flavors.  Not as much wheat as in the aroma, but sweeter.  Too much carbonation.  Finish is slightly metallic.  Overall decent, but too watery and the finish isnt too great.

Beer courtesy of my new neighbor, thanks mang. Beer seems crystal clear brownish orange with minimal head and what was there did not last long. Aroma is malty with some spice very light and crisp. Dry light flavour with mildly bitter caramel malts, grass,  elements of orange and pepper. Very easy drinking
What a great reprisentation. This beer has got to have the strongest malt aroma I have ever put my nose in. Wow. freaken love it.

Pours copper brown with small quickly diminishing off-white head. Aroma of sweet caramell and prunes. Flavor is all bread and caramell. A nice bitter finish but it felt as if the body was a bit too thin.

Bottle. Clear amber body. Fizzy, off-white head, mostly diminishing. The aroma is strongly malty and candy-like  caramel, toasted bread. Hints of flowers and honey and sugar. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes lightly to moderately sweet and lightly bitter. Nice sweet caramel first sip. Medium body, very watery texture and lively carbonation (nice fizzy finish). This is easy drinking (deceptive for almost 6% alcohol) though a little more hop presence in the finish would help the balance. Enjoyable.

Mély borostyán sárga színe,fehér hamar eltűnő vékony habja van.Illata picit karamellás,finom malátás.Az íz központjában is a maláta és annak édessége van egy kis fűszeres aromával.Aztán belép a komló is a maga kellemes kesernyésségével ami az utóízben is bőven ott van.Érezni az alkohol melegségét is rajta.Remek társasági ital.

12oz bottle. pretty good beer. amber body with a medium cream head. no lacing. smell was basic roasted malt and hops. taste was the same but a bit watery. a bit of a creamy mouthfeel and a medium hop bite.
Tried this around that time.  Malty and a bit corny with roasty hints and a dash of hops.

Serving: 12 oz. bottle.
Appearance: Nice deep amber color with a good sized, foamy, white head.  Decent head retention.
Aroma: Caramel malt, light biscuit notes, a bit of dustiness, and a wee bit of grassy hops.
Taste: Nice caramel malt sweetness up front, some grain notes, and a pleasant mix of biscuit and light hop bitterness.  A good showcase for the malt.
Palate: Medium, slightly prickly carbonation with a medium mouthfeel and a medium, slightly bitter finish.
Overall: Simple and well done.  A good example of the style.
Rebuy: Perhaps.  You certainly wont be disappointed by this.

12fl oz bottle poured into a dimpled mug.  Amber-brown with one finger off-white head.  Aroma is oakey with notes of dark fruit.  Flavor is basically the same.  Medium carbonation.  Lightly bitter finish.  Good brew.

This one poured a frothy tan, two-fingered head along with a clear, dark amber body.  The aroma was "interesting"; I could detect oranges, but little else.  The taste was just "different", hard to describe, but the longer it sat in the glass, the more the spices emereged and the better it tasted.  Mouthfeel was a bit thin, but the aftertaste was quite acceptable.  All in all, enjoyable and worthy of a second helping.

Appearance: Swing-top bottle, medium brown. Good amount of off-white head.
Aroma: Malt and some fruit. Slightly metallic.
Taste: Lots of malt, nice hops. Some caramel. Nothing special.
Info: 500ml bottle, 29/6-2009

Location: 12 oz bottle I believe I purchased it at Norms fall 08

Overall Impression: 
Pretty standard fest beer, enjoyed it. I like a good German fest beer, dont get me wrong, but they are all basically around the same score wise, not a style with a huge variance.  Not a bad score range, just not special beers.

The Darkest Oktoberfest I have yet to drink, this guy has no smell and the flavor is a wonderful full-bodies malty excursion. You could imagine that you just ate a mouthful of wheatgerm or the like when gulping this. Really good. $6.50 a pint at The Abbey Miami Beach

Bottled, swing top, 500ml from Westholme Stores, Goring on Thames, Oxon. Copper with white head. I really quite enjoyed this marzen, fruity full bodied, soft and pulpy in character, some caramel without getting dry, a little sweetish, but not much in the way of hops. Quite reasonable.
Pretty basic marzen. Medium body with average carbonation and no very outstanding flavors.
Draft @ Abbey Brewing Company. Pours clear copper color with of white ehad. Caramel malt aroma. Caramel flavor with a slight hoppiness and nuttiness. Medium body with average carbonation.
Bottle:  Amber colored pour with medium sized head.  Nutty, malty, caramel nose.  Malty, spicy, toffee caramel taste.
Amber orange color with an all right head.  Malty aroma and taste with nutty and caramel notes.  Pretty true to style.  Not bad but not great.

A Mes rate. Bottle at Quinns. Bright amber gold with a decent white head. A typical ofest marzen is all I have in my notes. Strange thing is, light on the ground as my notes are, they probably do a thoroughly good job of describing this beer. I guess its better than writing cheese tits or something....Earlier Rating: 12/14/2008 Total Score: 3.2A Mes rate. Bottle at Quinns. Bright amber gold with a decent white head. Straight forward Marzen with plenty of bread and straw with a spritely finish with a faint bitterness. Straight forward and typical.

A clear amber colored beer with a foamy beige head. The aroma of malts with sweets of fruits and some honey. The taste of a little sweet caramel with some fruits with a little bitterness. A little dusty. The aftertaste is bittersweet in a customary way.

This is a fairly quintessential Oktoberfest, perhaps not the greatest example but certinally about as represenative and classic as it gets. Pours clear a deep orangeish red with not a lot of head. Smells roasty and autumnal with a touch of metallic copper. The flavor is sweet, a little nutty with a faint noble hop flavor, largley malty but one of the nicer super malty beers I have had certinally some caramel flavor here.
This is easily the best Oktoberfest Ive ever had, absolutely incredible flavor, delicious
12oz bottle.  Pours an off-white head with an amber body.  Smells of bread and caramel.  Tastes of biscuits and caramel  Decent caramel finish.
Bottle.  Sweet malty aroma, some hops evident.  Orange-amber body, large off-white head.  Flavor is very sweet, caramel and malty, a bit syrupy.  Some alcohol in the finish.

Bottle:  Bright golden with a smaller, creamy head.  Sweet malty aroma with caramel and a little earthy.  Tastes floral hoppy up front into an earthy and malty finish.  A bready smooth transition into more light florals in the tail.  An enjoyable okto at xmas time.

Draught at The Abbot on the Hill Oktoberfest Dinner. Deep orange-amber with two fingers of snow white head. Aroma is malty and fruity, with notes of apricot and peach. Medium bodied. Flavour is solid and balanced, with a moderately bitter finish. A well made lager, I was glad to have tried it from a very fresh keg.

400ml draught 
5.8% ABV 
I tried this beer on October 14, 2008 at "The Beer Bistro" in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.  The beer poured a crystal translucent dark golden colour with a thin white head.  The aroma has some grainy malt hints, some hop hints, as well as some fruity hints like apricot.  The mouthfeel was medium bodied, and was lightly carbonated.  The flavour was grainy malt, and was very smooth.  This went down well

On tap at the Castle on King in September.  Great looking pour, medium yellow with orange and a good sized white head.  Malty aroma, almost a touch sweet, with some tinny hops.  Taste is decent - yeasty, malty/grainy with a bit of yeast and even a little alcohol.  Pretty refreshing.  Nothing blew me away, but it was a solid beer.
My favorite oktoberfest.  Malty, and caramel.  Really nice aroma and flavor.  this is one great beer.  Any october i am down for one of these.

Bottle.  Pours a yellow-apricot orange, with a small head.  Aroma of German hops, malt, and caramel.  Flavor is surprisingly tasty.  It is a soft mixture of sweet malts with some toffee, butterscotch, and soil.  Really nice.  I have been looking for a quaffable Oktoberfest, and in Hacker-Pschorr, I think Ive found it.

Pours an amber/red color with a nice white head.  Typical octoberfest aromas of caramel, spices, but I think a little wheat.  Flavor is mostly malts, specificially caramel.  Smooth and drinkable with a clean, lasting finish.  I definitely recommend.

Was looking for a marzen because of the season, this was recommended by the clerk of the local booze store. A really striking amber color with enough clearness to see every bubble rise to the half inch head. Very sweet malt aroma on this, candied malts. taste was a mild bitterness that does not offend and makes for easy drinking especially with such a light palate. I went out in search of pretzels to eat with my second bottle.
Bottle.  Pours an amber bdoy with a white head.  Malty and lightly spiced, caramel and some light grassy hops.  okay.

nice orange/amber color. The smell is typical Oktoberfest with Malt and Spices. Flavors were not quite as distinct and rich as I had hoped for, yet the malt does come through.

Overall a good and very drinkable beer, it is clean and smooth on the palate, with a clean after taste.
Amber. Medium head. Aroma: Caramel, bread, light hops. Flavor: Hops, bread, caramel, candy. Clean finish.  Nice beer.

Shared this one w/ SkyCop32.  Picked up at Maruhn Getränke in Darmstadt.   Pours a medium golden orange color.  Aromas of roast malts, caramel, and some hops.  Flavors of sweet malt, wheat bread and some nice hopping.
Pours brown with a small or no head and a caramel flavor.  Great flavor and nice aroma but lacks on taste after swallowed.

Had 3 or 4 of these over a pleasant afternoon. Nice taste but lacked the depth of flavor I was looking for. Came off a bit flat.... and reminded me of why I love Clipper Citys BaltoMarzen which is decidedly more complex and tasty.

This is a wonderful Oktoberfest with a nice taste of hops.  It pours a beautiful amber with a small white head.  The Palate is just average, but the flavor and aroma is just awesome!  The hops shine and the yeast gives it a slight twist.  Nicely Done!

Has a nice brown color with malty aroma.  Hints of caramel and coffee.  This is not one of the better Oktoberfest beers I’ve had but it’s not that bad.  Doesn’t have a that much of an aftertaste which is a pleasant ending.
Another good Ofest. Similair to Paulenar with SLIGHTLY less flavor to it. Still good though.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a reddish/amber color, kind of a cola color.  Very little head, dissipates quickly.  Aroma is malty, with molasses, caramel perhaps.  Flavor is also malty, with molasses, perhaps some creamy chocolate as well.  Some thickness in the palate.  Overall it’s good for an Oktoberfest, a fun, drinkable beer.

12oz bottle.  Pours a fairly dark amber with an off-white head.  Aromas of grain and malt, makes me think of a feed sack.  Body follows with pretty serious malt flavor, a bit of caramel.  Medium carbonation that tends to soft.  This is a pretty heavy duty oktoberfest.
Looks very nice.  Very drinkable and smooth.  But pretty boring otherwise.

Poured from the bottle into a pint glass.  Pour produced a red-brown body topped by a small, quickly diminishing head of foam.  Nose is slightly sweet with notes of spice and molasses.  Flavor is on the sweet side  with notes of burnt caramel.
Attractive deep ruddy brown pour with no head. The nose and flavor are subtly sweet with some roasted malt and caramel. Very dry finish.

12 oz bottle pours a medium golden brown with a small fluffy white head.  Wheat aroma with some clove.  Slightly sour, with wood, walnut, and caramel.  Almost chewy but not thick.  Slight hop bitterness with a dryness at the swallow.

On tap @ The Abbot on the Hill.







Aroma of nicely toasted malt,a light fruitiness, like freshly peeled apple skins, copper, small cream head, pretty lace. 
Taste is lovely roasted malt, caramel, flavour of pitfruits, woody, nutty notes too. Medium bodied, beautiful balance, wonderful mouthfeel. Splendid, an absolutely fine example.  Ein Prosit! Kudos to The Abbot, first in Canada with this on tap!

12 oz Bottle.  Pours clear amber with a medium beige head, good lacing.  Fruity and malty aroma, of figs, raisins and caramel.  Light, crisp body.  Delicious malt flavor, fruity and sweet, but well balanced, with subtle pine, almost vegetable noble hop finish and slight aftertaste.  Very refreshing and drinkable.

Pours a nut brown color with a thin head and some streaks along the sides of the glass. The nose is nice and nutty with hints of spice and bitter hops. The flavor is nice and bitter with fall spice that coats your palate as you take each sip. Overall it is refreshing and spicy with good finish and the right amount of bitterness.

12 oz bottle. Pours up nice and clear with a thick head. On the dark side for the style. Decent malt profile in the aroma with some fairly aggressive hopping for the style. Also get a slight mineral scent. Nice malt sweetness with some complexity with caramel notes the most powerful. Once again, bitterness is on the higher side for the style, but I find this ok. Seems to finish a bit thin. Overall, not bad, but there are better.

A nice surprise at the terrible bar where they have 6 taps of American pee-water macros and 1 tap of potluck.  Dry (I didn’t find it sour like some raters) with mild bitter finish, the color is on the reddish brown side for a German Oktoberfest.

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2011 Re-rate from the bottle. More light caramel and some light and clean hop notes. Very clean fermentation. Nice nuttiness to it and an improved score.

Bottle. Aroma is typical amber lager notes of caramel, clean yeastiness with a touch of Hallertau. Kind of reminiscent of normal Sam Adams. Decent Oktoberfest, though far from the best.
Bottle Swing-top: Poured a clear brown with a off white head. Aroma is sweet toffee and malt. Taste is a sweet caramel with a roasted nut malt hint.
2008 Bottle - Pours ambery orange with a large off white head...aroma is light malt and toffee, flavour is also light...not on par with the other marzens in my opinion, lacking depth...

I expected more from a beer with this kind of heritage. I honestly wasn’t all that impressed. It was pretty complex, I’ll give it that. I was turned off by how sour it was. Maybe I had a bad bottle. It wasn’t excessively sour, but just enough to make me reach for something else within minutes.
From bottle on recommendation... pours dark amber, with small white head. Crisp, caramel malt aroma with similar taste. Clean finish. Quite enjoyable.
Nice clear amber color with no head.  Aroma of roasted malts, mild hops and caramel.  Flavor of roasted malts, hops ,with some caramel sweetness.  Nice finish.

Bottle.  Poured caramel amber with a foamy cream head.  Aroma is slightly sweet and malty.  Taste is similar - clean cereal grain and caramel malt.  Finish is slightly bitter and spicy.  Very nice fall seasonal.

Nice appearance with a clear dark amber body and a foamy stable beige head. Caramel-bayern malt aroma with a hint of a floral hop perfume. Smooth mouthfeel, spicy taste of caramel malt, sweet grains, good balanced carbonation. Nice hop flavor in the aftertaste. One of the best lagers what i’ve ever tasted.
Pretty good Oktoberfest.  Clear dark amber color with quickly diminishing head.  Carmel malt taste.  Crystal clear body.  Light to medium bodied with a watery texture.
On tap at Flying Pie Boise, pours out amber topped with a sand head. Aroma of sweet malts and a nice spice. Tast more of the fall malts and light spice. A nice fall brew.

UPDATED: SEP 9, 2011 Pours a clear dark amber with a medium, off white head.  Sweet, malty taste with hints of spiciness and caramel.  Slight hints of honey as well.  Good traditional festbier from Germany.

Beer looks amber and it has a nice beige head that goes away quickly but leaves a translucent oily lacing. Malty aroma with some caramel hints. The taste was ok with caramel and malts. My complaint however was in the rather metallic finish. Overall a good beer to swill in large quantities.

On tap at the Castle. Taps a very nice dark amber colour with a large beige, but quickly diminishing head. Aroma is fairly faint actually, some earthiness with decent Munich malts and Hallertrau hops. Flavour is good, but again, kind of bland and faint. Nice and malty sweet the whole way through, but dominated by a lot of weird dry hoppy astringency followed by a surprising alcoholic kick. Medium, slightly full mouth-feel, which works to its advantage. Despite the unpleasant unexpected aspects, this is still a very enjoyable beer. I wish they served this at our KW Oktoberfest instead of the usual MacroMania. I guess I expected a little more delicious malty awesomeness out of my first ever Marzen, but this is still a great beer.

12oz. Bottle:  Malts, dough, bitter hops, pretzel, bread, grains, and caramel.  Poured amber in color with a small, tan head that disappeared quickly.  Clear.  Not sparkling.  Light to medium sweet, lightly bitter flavor.  Tastes of malts, dough, pretzel, salt, bitter hops, cardboard, and a hint of caramel.  Light to medium body.  Average texture.  Average carbonation.  Malty, salty, finish.

500 ml bottle.  Pours a beautiful amber color.  Sweet malt flavor, with a hint of honey...just like it says in the company’s description.  I usually prefer regular German lagers to the Oktoberfest beers, but this one is quite good.

Brewed in Germany. Pours a nice amber color with a dissipating white head. Aroma of caramel, malts, and bread. The taste is of mild hops, caramel, and a hint of honey. The mouthfeel is a bit sweet, but refreshing.  This is another enjoyable brew from Hacker-Pschorr.

Yes, it’s fall now and time for oktoberfest, a beer style that really seems to suit its season, and this is a pretty good one.  Nice malty backbone, sweet with a hint of grassy hops in the finish. Not spectacular but quite drinkable.

dry with a nice smooth texture to the palate, would like to see a hint more carbonation. sweet and malty just barely nutty with a refined and mismatched hop profile in keeping with the style and therefore understood. just good for the style and maybe lacking that connotation for my type of brew sorry i am what i am. finish is busy but not intriguing. final bitterness that is just a bit too understated.
12oz bottle served in a lager glass.  Copper body topped by a creamy head. Smells of dough, caramel, and a touch of spicy hops. Taste is bread and noble hops. Simple but effective. Decent fest beer.

The rich, woody amber liquid raises a small, finely-beaded snowy froth. A saturating nutty/toasty  “barley mash” nose erupts from the glass, and decadent notes of flowers, baking cookies, dark rum, and wet sycamore tree transform the aroma into something downright sensual. The flavor begins with rich nutty malt, rife with melanoidins (think fresh homebaked bread and searing meat)… and accentuates with pollen, pipe tobacco, charred wood and appleskin. The finish features warm bitterness and a surprisingly sharp flash of alcohol. Almost light in body, a fullish- almost greasy- texture contributes friction. This beer crumbles in the aftertaste, which somewhat echoes the flavor but ends with a lingering alkaline, fishy quality that completely ruins the whole experience. Overall, very promising to start with, but “wonky” and disappointingly far less smooth than expected.

This beer began the third round of my home beer tasting tournament: Traditional Germans- featuring Marzens and unique wheat beer styles.  This lager was a very deep amber, slightly dark for a marzen, ruby and reflective, with a large,  joyously frothy head.  There is strong caramel and toffee in the aroma, due in large to the Munich malt,  as well as surprisingly fruity notes of cherries and honey, leaving this brew feeling heavily toasted and appetizing.  The body is firm, yet smoothly subtle with slight smoke, overripe fruit, and dark burnt malt overtones.  Delicious and easy to drink all day long, this is a wonderful ruby/amber lager with which to celebrate good times- whether it be the largest beer festival in the world or a backyard beer tasting.  The finish is brisk, stickly sweet, and ends slightly dry with a hint of grassy hallertau hops.
Bottle.  Clear amber pour with an off white head.  Aroma of malt, bread and mild hops.  Taste of caramel, hops and faint plums.  Nice smooth finish, really good session brew.

Drinking beer and talking about beer always gets me in the mood to watch BEERFEST!!! That aside, whether it’s October or June, I am always in the mood to quaff a delicious Oktoberfest brew, and Hacker-Pschorr presents a fine example of this classic marzen.


From the bottle into my glass, she pours a bright golden brown with a creamy, foamy head which lingers around the rim of the glass long after. Caramel and bready malt in the nose, maybe a bit of apple. I can def taste the faint hint of apple that I got in the nose, along with smooth mild malt sweetness. I get a lingering bit of hop bite on the top back of the tongue after each swallow. As the Hacker-Pschorr Oktoberfest warms a bit, I get more of the bready mouth feel mixed in with the apple and caramel. Watching tiny bubbles swim to the top of my glass, I find myself transported to Germany, sitting at a long table, throwing back my beer, and watching the festivities with a silly grin on my face. She finishes sweet with a hop flourish.

Hacker-Pschorr Oktoberfest is definitely one of the best examples of this style. I have had Paulaner and Sam Adams, and H-P is still my favorite.

Bottle. Pours a deep amber body with nice head. Aroma is pleasant, sweet maltiness. Flavor is smooth, sweet malt is dominating the taste, light creaminess to it and a very smooth creamy mouthfeel. The flavor seemed to slowly slide down my tongue. This was quite a surprise. Best Marzen I ever had!

user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Golden-brown color and clear. Has an off-white head, huge and lasting. Aroma is mostly sweet, caramel. Flavor is heavy sweet. FInish is lightly bitter. Syrup texture.
A nice beer.  Pours a dark brown with a nice toffee aroma.  The flavor is a delicious malty and caramel combination.  A very good seasonal beer, especially for its price.
Tap. Poured dark gold with off white head. Aroma of sweet malt and toffee. Nice sweet caramel flavor with some hops.
Toffee/caramel/malt, and not much else...which is a good thing IMHO for a Marzen.  Orange color with thick, fluffy head from a bottle.
reddish brown appearance witha strong malty nose.  flavor is sweet and nutty but has little complexiity and an average beer
Mostly this seemed a bit flat. The flavor was a little too malty and it just didnt have any crispness. Of course, its hard to say how it was handled, but it didnt impress too much.

The 12 ounce bottle poured a beautiful clear orange-amber colored beverage with a modest smooth white head that was mostly diminishing but left good lacing on the glass. The aroma was a nice balance of malts and hops with an outstanding caramel character dominating with notes of honey and floral hops taking a back seat. The body was medium-full with soft carbonation and a smooth soft texture or mouthfeel. The flavor starts out somewhat sweet showing off the caramel. The sweetness lasts almost through the finish slowly being replaced by a light pleasant bitterness.
UPDATED: JUL 22, 2007 Pours a solid orange carmel color with a puffy head. Tastes of toffee and caramel and malt. Very smooth mouthfeel. Pretty good.

Rated 11/6/06:  Lone sixer left on the shelves, marked down priced to sell. I felt bad for the little sixer and what I went there for was gone so I picked up figuring what the heck one last Oktoberfest for the season. Sweet bready light aroma with some loose change metallic scent. Wonderful initial pour medium bronze with a HUGE head that ultimately settles to very thin, some lacing remains on the rim. Easy on the gullet and rather drinkable, aftertaste is mellow. Flavor is grainy, grassy and dang theres that metallic hint. Almost like a nickel was dropped in the glass. Its an alright marzen, would be much better without the metallic hints, according to the bottle its only about 5 months old so it should still be fresh, just think its got a touch of the euro-transferitis.

A world class Oktoberfest-Marzen. Beautiful Hallertauer hop aroma with a carmelly malt nose interplays with each other. A smooth texture on first sip with a rich toasted malt flavor and just the right amount of hop bitterness. The amber/orange color makes it even more appetizing for a fall day.

Tap.  Pours to a thin amber rust body with a thin white head.  The aroma is milky and grainy with silage and corn.  Corn husks.  The flavor is husky and grainy and seems to have some lactose in it.  The palate seems to be slightly metallic and too husky and astringent.  Not a fan.
Bottle.  Gold/orange/copper.  A bit too clear of a color.  Sweet and malty aroma.  Sweet flavor with caramel tones.  Crisp and smooth finsh.  Refreshing.  Easy to drink.

Bottled. A golden-orange beer with an orange head. The aroma is sweet malty with notes of hops and caramel, as well as lighter notes of floweres and dust. The flavor is sweet malty with primary notes of caramel.
Bottle. Amber colour with a big off-white head. Light caramel malt, floral aroma and a sweet caramel malt taste. Medium body with a sweet finish.

(Bottle 50 cl) Clear, amber golden with a creamy, off-white head leaving some laces. Clean, malty aroma with a touch of honey. Medium body with a lightly sweet caramel flavour and a dry finish. Very clean. 290407

Bottled. Light amber coloured. Unclear. Dense beige head. Sweetness, fruits and light rye bread in the aroma. Flavour is fruity and light flowery. Has a light spiced touch. Is medium bodied. Sweetish and light bitter end. Very good seasonal.

Bottle. Average fizzy beige head that mostly lasted. Good lacing. Light cloudy body with a golden color. Aroma was a lovely mix of dry/dusty and malty notes. Rye bread, grain, toasted, floral and fruity notes. Medium bodied with an average carbonation. Moderated sweet flavor with good balancing bitterness. Somewhat dry and light sweet finish. Thought this was a pretty good beer.
An easy to drink large bottle import from the D&W in EGR before  it stopped carrying a good selection of beer. Malt flavor, bitter aftertaste, not a whole lot to speak of.
UPDATED: APR 30, 2007 12oz bottle. Had this one awhile ago. I remember it was nothing special, tasted some malts, overall decent beer. I need to retry this though.
I enjoyed this one. It is easy to drink but not especially complex. Slightly thin taste. Mostly malty, with some bitterness in the aftertaste.

Like a recent reviewer I picked this sample bottle up labled as an "original oktoberfest. Date on the lalel shows August of 05 and I just drank it March of 07 and it doesnt seem any the worse for wear.
I agree with other reviewers that aroma and appearance outweight the rather thin taste and slighty too bitter finish for this style of beer..still, Ive had far worse.

Poured from a 355ml bottle into a pint glass, amber with a medium tan head. Aroma was primarily sweet malt. Taste was the same, sweet malt with a watery mouthfeel. Very thin. Nothing offensive, but not much stands out.

This bottle is over a year out of date, and none the worse for it. Aroma is sweet malts, grasys hops cutting through. Taste is similarly swet a little grainy on the malts, but still a satisfying fucker!
The bottle I have is "Original Oktoberfest" which came out of a sampler box. The color is typical Octoberfest with a rich carmel color. Has a bitterness that I dont care for as it finishes.

12oz. Bottle

Hacker-Pschorrs Oktoberfest poured a very light copper. This is one of the clearest beers I have ever seen. 1 finger micro bubble head that took a little time to dissolve. What make this beer look good Is how clear it is.

The smell is malty and sweet.Thats about all Im getting from it. It has a pretty weak nose on it.

The taste is alright Its a little lacking as well but theres bready qualities followed by just a touch of sweetness and it seems like a little fruit. Theres a bitterness at the end that is coming from roasted malt.

The mouthfeel is good. Its medium bodied with that chalky texture. One of the better aspects of this brew.

Drinkability is a little above average but nothing special. Its a beer you could drink a lot of considering the texture and mouthfeel but when you bring the taste and smell into it would you really want to?

Sampled 10/4/06
Clear and copper with med carb, with a light long l;asting head. Smells of apples. pears,  apple juice and toffee. Sweet malty flavors with a firm malt background and a good malty finish.

Bottle (2005 version). A copper coloured Oktoberfest beer brewed in the traditional Marzen style. I ahve found each year that there are differences in depth of flavour. This beer I consider to be the best of the 2005 Oktoberfest beers.  A well balanced malty flavour with a long finish.
Orange, small white head.  Very malty/caramelly aroma and similar flavor.  Too thin but good flavor and decent slightly bitter finish.

Bottle. Clear light amber (copper) color with a small to average fair lacing white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toffe. honey ? and some notes of alcohol. Flavor is moderate sweet, and ligth to moderate bitter. Body is ligth to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft, finish feel is metalic.
Light amber color, sweet aroma with hints of caramel and toasty malt.  Body is malty, with caramel, mild bitterness, and a hint of herbs.  Not bad.
Apparently this IS the beer sold in North America.  Gold pour, big white head, lots of malt and mustiness in the aroma.  Good, clean taste of sweet malt and sugary caramel.  Decent.

Pours straight amber-orange..good sized head for the pour, leaves some good lacing!...smells atad dusty, and some strange caramel too....what a simple taste, crap honestly, for a german oktoberfest..never again.

UPDATED: DEC 5, 2006 If anything this beer should have had more hops. It was a little weak to me. It was a dark orange with a brown head. Most prevalent taste is the roasted malts you taste at the end.

Sampled by the bottle during early Oc(k)tober days.  The caramel aroma was fruity and sweet.  It had a dark orange/brown color with a light tan head that was gone quickly.  There was ample carbonation with a medium body, and the beer had a sweet and bitter finish.

Wife picked a beauty. It poured hazy chestnut with a lite tan, pearlescent dissipating head. Spicy aroma, gingerbread with a hint of oranges. The flavor is sweet, roasted malts, slightlybitter, cinnamon. Smooth, full mouthfeel with adequate carbonation. Lush and flavorful.

Pours a translucent golden/orange amber with a creamy off white head.  Aroma was sweet and malty, some corn, dough, graines and cereal.  Nutty with hints of caramel malt as well.  Flavor was very clean and crisp, yet with lots of flavor.  Grains, malty, hints of sweetness. Some caramel, toffee and nuts.  This is how an Marzen should be!
Bottle.  Caramel and toffee flavors.  Malty taste.  Very good flavor, with little head.

(Draught at Man in the Moon, Stockholm, 18 Oct) Amber colour with rocky white head. Malty,  nutty nose with caramel and toffee. Malty taste with toffee, caramel, dried apricots and raisins. Toasty notes and moderately bitter finish. Fairly nice but almost too much caramel.

had this on tap. poured dark amber and had a small thin head. a little hint of pear, and flowery yet a small bit of caramel to the fragrance. Smooth beer, not much aftertaste. was not bitter to me at all.

12oz bottles. Great festival beer. Pours dark reddish amber. small white head. aromas of carmel malts and hops. small bodied overall refreshingly balanced flavor of malts and hops with hints of cloves and citrus. Very traditonal marzen, one of my favorites.

(Bottled) Deep, dark amber color with a very small head. Caramely-malty aroma with some diacetyl. Caramely-malty flavor with buttery diacetyl. Light to medium-bodied palate with balanced carbonation. A quite enjoyable märzen, if one doesnt mind the diacetyl.
Another nice Hacker Pschorr beer.  Dark amber colored beer with an off white head.  Flavor of roasted malt and caramel.  A bit sweeter than I remember in years past.

Light orange colored, medium sized yellow head. Aroma is good with caramel, hops, some bockish spices and mild chocolate. Medium bodied. Flavor is also fine with hops, caramel, some bitterness, chocolate and berries, mild alcohol there too. Aftertaste dries with some caramel.
Draught. Pours a reddish amber colour with a small white head. Sweet malty aroma with some bready hints. Sweet malty bready flavor, with some hints of caramel. Malty finish with some bitterness.
Very nice.  Grainy and malty, but the hops are there too.  Superb balance.  Nobody touchs the Ayinger though.
Its good to have a German beer that stick close to what a Marzen should taste like. Good amount of Caramel malts with little hops for the that Harvest taste.

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2006 All the notes are subtle- underneath the yeasty biscuit/wheat taste there are faint  hints of mineral, spice/clove,  orange/lemon, pumkin. Best Oktoberfest style Ive tried so far. Just a little chalkiness that is off putting for me.

Pours orange-amber into a shaker.  Fluffy medium head leaves no lacing as it recedes.  Malty Okto aromas. Upfront sweet caramel with a bitter, lasting finish turns back to malt.  Medium bodied and well balanced.

Clear orange, creamy off white head.  Nose held notes of toasted toffee chips, with soft touches of dark fruit, grains, biscuit.  Upon warming, just a faint herbal tone appears too.  Authentic German flavors that remain toasty, lightly bready, with faint raisin tones.  Medium bodied, medium carbonation, drying toasty finish.  Not a favorite style, but this was quite nice...

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2008 Ive waited a pretty long time to taste a hacker.  Actually, Ive been waiting for a kristel, dunkle weiss or a weiss bock, but this came around first. On the bottom left hand corner of the label it says OK+ !  Do you know about the German purity law of 1516? It must be a good law, because this is good beer. When it hits your togue there is a slight flavor of hops, but very litlle, if any hop bitterness.  How refreshing!  The finish lacks the lasting bitterness of boiled hops that everyone else around here is so proud of, and Im glad of it. I have visions of a pretty frua-lien in a long red skirt with only a bustenhalter, holding my beir while she is riding toward me on a big black horse, side-saddle!! I eagerly anticipate my next hacker. Not dissapointed. This is not yer typical pale yellow american style beer by any means.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: 12 oz Bottle:  Pours a reddish amber color with a small soapy white head.  Aroma is pumpkin, orange, lightly hopped, yeast, and sticky bread with a bit of sugar.  Taste is nice roasted maltiness to it, with some definite caramel notes, and that same bready texture to the scent in the taste.  Palate is lightly sweet, somewhat carbonated and medium bodied.  Overall, This is has a nice roasted flavor for a Marzen.  This is really drinkable and would be an excellent session beer.  Nice Okroberfest Beer!

A well balanced brew great for drinking en masse.  I couldnt find much to love about this beer.  I was expecting more caramelized barley flavor.   I would surely pick up a case for a party in a pinch, or maybe even once a year to cleanse my beer palate.
Fine Oktoberfest with a perfect blend of malt and hops. My second favorite Oktoberfest to Spaten, which I find a bit drier.

Bottle.  Poured with a big ole head that dissipated rapidly atop this clear copper brew.  Strong malt scent with some rich earthy grassy notes from the hops.   Exceptinally well balance with a rich body and a touch of clove in the flavor.  Finishes with crisp ho bitterness.  A very nice Oktoberfest.

Copper brown, small white head. Malty, some toasted bread and caramel in the nose. Rye-malty, medium-bodied with sweetish finish. Caramelly malty aftertaste. Solid oktoberfestbeer.
Draught. Amber colour, big beige head. Aroma of Märzen a a bit caramel. Same In flavour. Not that exciting but it is a very clean and welldone Oktoberfestbrew.
Pours amber with a small head. Caramel aroma, some floral hops, could be stronger. Nice flavor, some bitterness.

Pours clear darkish golden with a small white head. Malty caramel aroma with also some grain and flowery hops. the flavour is quite similar, with caramel, grain and flowery hops running the show. The bitterness is quite high for the style, and the finish is grainy and medium length.

Pours Amber with good head retention. Good caramel flavor and some roasted malts. Not my favorite Oct fest but a good one.

Good brew
Bottle, BevMo La Mesa. Pours a very dark amber color. Sweet cereal aroma with some maltiness. Toasty flavor. Some bitterness. Has some of the same grainy qualities as cereal.
Solid Marzen offering.  I love this type of brew.  Medium-light body offers hours of enjoyment through numerous fests.  Great hops all around and strong finish.

(swing top bottle)  Clear, amber colour with a mid-sized, slowly lacing, slightly off-white foamy head. Moderately sweet malty, toasted bread aroma with faint hints of herbal hops. Sweet and slightly bitter flavour, medium to light body with a crispy carbonation. Toasted malty taste, bready with light herbal notes, rather dry, moderately bitter and toasty finish with hints of liquorice. Well-balanced and easy-going session-Märzen.

[Draught at Delirium Café, Göteborg, Sweden]
Deep red-amber colour with good head. Big caramelly, concentrated, clean aroma. Long boil feel here. Very malty feel to it. Bit candy-ish in flavour, with toffee and milk chocolate. Not the regular Märzen-prickly feeling but tasty!
Very nice ruby body with a thick ivory head.  Enjoyed at Capital Ale Houses Oktoberfest..  Lightly fruity with some nice malt and hop backbone.  Very enjoyable and drinkable in large quantities.

Sweet welcoming of caramel malt and sugar found in the aroma. Color is a crystal clear see through orange and fizzy film on top. Marzen is carbonated well enough and has a easy going palate that makes this an very quaffable beer. Some signs of sweetness in the flavor but overall the flavor is subdued and subtle.

Bottle at LCRBM 2, Kulminator, Antwerp, Belgium Clear, orange to amber body.  Aroma of hops, soap, not very interesting and rather bad.  Moderately bitter flavour.  Quite soapy. Didnt like this at all.

On tap at Mahars. Best beer of the night. Poured a great ruby red, with a beautiful crowning white head. Aroma is very spicy and sweet. Flavor was sweet, and very spicy, tasted like a good octoberfest should.

um, pretty much just looks like a clear amber ale.  smells very much like pistachios and nuts, and strong malts.  bock-like as well.  getting a ton of apple too. no flavor in the front end, but then theres plenty.  id say flavor is malt dominated, but its not particularly strong.  a bit empty :-/  the aroma is definitely the most distinctive thing about this.  id rather have a retro encabulator

06 batch.Sweet roasted malt taste.
Not much hops to balance the flavour.
I pick up this brew every year,and
every year it is more watery.30%
of all beer brewed in Munich is consumed at the annual Octoberfest.

Bottle.  Amber with a light head, minimal lacing.  A sweet aroma of malt, hint of spice.  Very smooth flavor with hints of malt, pumpkin/cinnamon (?) spice, a bit metalic at the finish, very odd.  Leaves a tingling sensation on the tongue.  I like it, sophisticated yet simple.  This is what I will be drinking for Oktoberfest 2006.

UPDATED: OCT 6, 2006 Malty aroma with a touch of cinnamon? or brown-sugar? Creamy flavor, along with the body with a nice malty bite, which is slightly caramel like. Light, balancing bitterness in the finish. Nice Oktoberfest.

Kind of a malty cowpasture pour. Sweet malts with roasted nuttiness. Some pumpkin like hints. Dances around a chewy side then lances down a earthy tone. A very decent Oktoberfest....i cant wait for Oktober!

12 oz. bottle.  Deep amber with a thick tan head.  Aroma of sweet malt.  Sweet malty flavor with some roasted notes.  Smooth finish.  Fall beers are a lot more interesting than most summer beers.  Extra points for the history of the style.

O Zapft Is!  Had to run out and get an Oktoberfest today...the offical start of the festival.  Just need some hendel to go with this delicious brew.  Sweet malty aroma.  Chewy white head that lasted.  Strong malt flavor at the start finishing w/ a nice hop edge.  I just need a Mass and some lederhosen and Im back...

I had this last night at Bodega downtown La Crosse, Wisconsin. It just arrived at the bar in both bottles and on draft. I had a mug of draft and a bottle poured into the same kind of mug to compare side by side. The draft was very obviously lighter in color and after tasting lighter in body, flavor, and aroma. In fact the draft is a bit watery/thin. Both had light head with a bit of lace that faded. Mild flavor. Sadly has continuously gone downhill since days of yore.

Amber in appearance, very minimal head. Aroma and flavor have plenty of toasted malt and caramel. Getting a really strong fruit character out of this, quite the turn-off. Finishes sort of metallic, with residuel sugars. Just average at best.
Clear light amber body with a thin tan head. Sweet malty aroma. Sweet malty flavor with some light hop hints.

To truly appriciate this beer, you kind of need a salty first full sausage or some other saline rich foods. It is beacuse there is such a precise balance hiding behind those sweet malts up front. Nothing is pushed forward with out an equally forceful counter step, whther it is the dry body that follows the caramal sweet nose, or the strong finishing note following the surprisingly light-footed body. I wonder why the American craft versions rate higher than this precisely crafted version. They show off more I guess. This is a beer on a lie detector: nothing but the truth.
This sheet be dank my homies. Yum yum. Hallertau owns. Pretty malty caramelly goodness. I love the fall.
Deep amber/copper color. Aroma of malts, caramel. Full flavored beer with an earthy roasted malt taste balanced by a mild hop addition in the finish. Good Oktoberfest beer.

I remember drinking these at Oktoberfest last year.  Goes great with salty rotisory chicken by the way.  Amber, orange in color.  caramael malty aroma  with a good balance of hops and a slight raisin taste.  A real fine crafted brew.

Bottled.  Yummy caramel malts in both the aroma and flavor and a nice finish of some sort of continental hops.  Visually nice, with  a medium lasting off-white head on top of a clear, pale copper body. Nothing too complex, but a very enjoyable brew when all the elements are put together.

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2012 Bottle, bought @ Edeka, Allershausen.
Pours a lovely copper with a fine, staying, creamy, white head. Aroma has rye bread, sweet malts, soft grass. Medium carbonation, fine dryish and creamy mouthfeel. Flavour is quite sweet, caramel, still some rye bread, chewy malts. Lingering mild bitter grassy finish.
Amber body, beautiful white head, leaving laces; Balanced, pleasant nose; Quite bitter body, a little sweet; Long bitter finish. Very nice and very well made beer.

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2007 Re-Rate...Pours golden amber with a frothy white head. Light aroma of caramel, and barley malt. Flavor follows th aroma nicely. Palate is light/medium, very smooth mouth-feel, with a lightly sweet finish.
A very smooth brew, primarily tasting of yeasty bread and smooth caramel on the tongue. Just a bit of hops in the finish. Overall, not a bad brew at all, though far from incredible.
12oz bottle-pours a fizzy, foamy offwhite head with copper color.  Aroma is caramel malt, slight bitter hops.  Taste is sweet caramel malt, secondary bitter hops.  Good effervescence.

Bottle 48F Lager.  Slighty sour aroma, with a light maltiness a bit of pepper, subtle yeast but not to much bread.  Light Copper color with a large and frothy white head, the germans are masters of displaying frothy head.  Clear color looks nice and inviting. A sweet touch begins the drink followed by a nice slightly sour to very mildly bitter finish.  Maybe a touch of metal, slight iron I think. Nice ceral finish.  Very tight carbonation very full of bubbles but the viscosity is light and goes down quickly.  Good lightly roasted beer, with light touches of carmel. Good and easily drinkable.

500ml. Pours a medium amber with a bit of quickly dissipating white head. Pleasantly billowing sweet malty bread on the nose, though the billowing calms down as quickly as does the head. Lots of yeast and bread on the palate, very little hop. In the end, theres not much happening here.
Bottle.  Poured a deep amber with a an average head and some lacing.  Great malt taste with some biitterness.  Really enjoyed this brew.

UPDATED: AUG 8, 2007 Swing top bottle. Bought at De Man van Drank Leiden. One month past best before date. Amber color, dense head. Pear and just a touch of dust in the aroma. Malty but vinous beer. Raisin and hops in the background, even a touch of cinnamon. Butterscotch and some bitterness in the aftertaste.
(6 3 6 2 11 = 2.8)
A fresh sample bought in Nordhorn was much better. Loads of malt and toffee in the aroma. Medium to full bodied. malty sweet flavor, bready, cake, pear. Grassy hopbitterness in the aftertaste. Lovely well balanced beer.

12oz "Original Oktoberfest"  with Amber Marzen written just below. Clear dark gold to orange color with very thin white head. Strong malt aroma. Mostly lightly roasted or Vienna type malts. There is also a subtle hint of yeast too. The aroma is truly mouth watering. Tasty malty flavor. Nice, but not too sweet, grain malt flavor followed by some sweeter malts. At the same time the sweet malts hit some bitter hop flavor enters the picture to reign in the sweetness. Excellent October-fest beer. Most in this style end up being too sweet for my tastes. But not this one.

This one didnt do much for me within the style. Poured with a better head than some of the others of its class and with the normal amber-orange color. The aroma was somewhat caramel-like and malty. The flavor featured caramel malts, low roastedness (I would have liked more), even some grassiness (which Im not a fan of). For an original German, not overly impressive. Too sweet and nothing to help balance it out. Id drink it again, but Id certainly choose a few others over this one, which is surprising #3 on the site (within style) as of today.

5 liter keg can. Pours amber\copper with a decent sized off-white head. Aroma of caramel malts, citrus, and yeast. Flavor is a full bodied malty delight, caramel malts, mildly carbonated, yeast, citrus. Good brew.

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2007 Pours a beautiful copper color w/ a  modest head that degenerates quickly to a skimpy, thin ring. Aromas of stewed veggies and sweet malts spew forward. Medum nectar w/ mellow residual effers. The texture is thin and soft. Big fruity malts, w/ said stewed veggies and herbs. The finish is bttered gently and leaves a lingering malty sweetness to ponder.

"not sure why this is so highly rated, kind of ho hum for me. Poued a nice amber color with a nice head to it. Aroma was carmel malts. Flavor was fmalty and raosted flavor a grass after taste to it which i didnt expect. Mouthfeel was okay refreshing but flavor killded this one.

Poured the color of maple syrup with no head. The aroma was sweet and malty and resembled a dopplebock. Flavor was sweet malts, carmel, bread, and some hops and yeast. Kind of had a barleywine taste to it. Finish was fairly spicey with a little kick to it.
Whats to say? Its a pretty decent Oktoberfest. Comes in the bigger 500ml bombers, and is pretty amiable all around.
Pours red amber with breif off-white head.  Strong aroma of roasted caramel malts and yeast.  Flavor is of malt with a mild yeast presence.  Personally I prefer Paulaner.

A mid orange-copper brown coloured beerwith a thick white head.  A strong aroma of malt and caramel with a yeasty element, slightly soapy. The beer is fizzy on the mouth. Yeasty flavour with malt and some sweetened fruit, like ripe bananas. The finish is fizzy yet sweet and malty. Bottle - purchased from the Beers of Europe.

Amber with a nice white head.  Aroma of figs, caramel, and honey, with a touch of banana to boot.  Thick and malty, lots of fig, caramel. and honey in the flavor.  Smooth, relatively heavy mouth feel.  One of my favorites of the style.

On tap at the Hessen Haus during the 2006 Crescent Moon Beer Bus Trip. Medium gold in color with a white head. Straw-like aroma and subtle honey-malt smell. VERY SMOOTH! Very nice malt content. Not similar to the Hacker fest bier that I tried at Die Wiesen.

With all the high ratings this beer was a little dissapointing.  Pours an univiting orange-amber color with a one-finger creamy head that dissapated rather quickly.  The aroma was citrusy and slightly yeasty with the faintest toasty note.  It hits the tongue with an overpowering carbonation and a medium-thin body (thinner than other Ofests Ive tried).  The taste is malty, slightly nutty with a citrus hop finishing into the aftertaste, which is mildly sweet and dry.  In comparison to other Ofests, it was thin, with too lively of a carbonation, and not enough rich malt, toasty flavor.  Not bad, but nothing compared to the flagship of Ofests, Paulaner.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2007 This one was from a fairly old bottle but it tasted fresher than a lot of less out-of-date beers Ive had.  I enjoyed this one greatly.  It had no sourness: just a rich malt, leaving a very pleasant aftertaste.  The texture was smooth and rich.  There wasnt really much to this beer, it was fairly simple, but well done.  Maybe if I had it fresh it would be even better!

(500 ml bottle: $2.49 at Bottleworks in Seattle, WA) Its been a long time coming.  Seven years since I last saw this beer on shelves, and I had to drive to Seattle to find it!  The date printed on the bottle label is 06.05, so I presume that means its six months old.  This is one of my favorite imported Oktoberfests, proudly and prominently putting on display the luscious, up front German malty character that I just cant seem to find in any domestic release.  Its a bit more caramely and earthier than I remember, possibly due to the moderate aging.  The moderate hop bitterness lends perfect balance, complementing the moderately sweet malts from sip to finish.  Fairly dry maltiness in the nose, not much hoppiness, but a bit too earthy.  Body is medium with nice carbonation and a fairly smooth palate.  Could stand to be a bit cleaner and crisper though.  I have the glass of beer on a small shelf on my desk, with a lamp off to the side, and this beer is nearly textbook in appearance.  It is medium amber in color, shows a stunning clarity, and a dozen or so streams of very tiny carbonation bubbles crawl at a snails pace toward the surface.  The head is ivory in color, but doesnt show particularly impressive retention, rising to nearly an inch in height, but then settling to a filmy layer with five minutes or so.  And theres no lacing on the glass.  Some of the domestic Oktoberfest releases are tasty in their own right, but they are Americanized versions.  When I pick up an Oktoberfest, I prefer the classic German flavor on display here.  Id probably prefer the draft version in Germany, but Ive not been afforded that luxury yet.  Can only imagine, and dream...
